head.title: Identifying Activity and Selectivity Trends for the Electrosynthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide via Oxygen Reduction on Nickel–Nitrogen–Carbon Catalysts | The Journal of Physical Chemistry C

meta.content: Identifying Activity and Selectivity Trends for the Electrosynthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide via Oxygen Reduction on Nickel–Nitrogen–Carbon Catalysts

The electrocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) through the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) requires cost-effective catalysts with high selectivity, activity, and stability. Herein we report the synthesis and electrocatalytic assessment of nickel–nitrogen–carbon (Ni–N–C) electrocatalysts to gain insight into ORR activity and selectivity toward the production of H2O2. The activity and selectivity of the catalysts depended on the amount of nickel added during synthesis as well as the pH of the electrolyte. The materials were found to be heterogeneous in nature, consisting of nitrogen-doped carbon structures containing Ni species, including Ni3S2 and covered metallic Ni particles. The presence of Ni during synthesis was imperative for the ORR performance in acidic electrolytes but had minimal impact on the performance in alkaline electrolytes. By experimentally demonstrating that Ni3S2, metallic Ni, and N-doped carbon species were not the source of activity, we postulate that atomically dispersed Ni–Nx/C sites are responsible for the ORR performance in acidic electrolytes, with an activity of −0.3 mA cm–2 and a H2O2 selectivity of 43% measured for the best Ni–N–C catalyst at 0.5 V vs RHE. This work highlights the potential and generates scientific insight into Ni–N–C catalysts to guide the design of improved performance metal–nitrogen–carbon catalysts based on inexpensive precursors and simplistic syntheses.

div.p:
The electrocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
) through the two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) requires cost-effective catalysts with high selectivity, activity, and stability. Herein we report the synthesis and electrocatalytic assessment of nickel–nitrogen–carbon (Ni–N–C) electrocatalysts to gain insight into ORR activity and selectivity toward the production of H
2
O
2
. The activity and selectivity of the catalysts depended on the amount of nickel added during synthesis as well as the pH of the electrolyte. The materials were found to be heterogeneous in nature, consisting of nitrogen-doped carbon structures containing Ni species, including Ni
3
S
2
and covered metallic Ni particles. The presence of Ni during synthesis was imperative for the ORR performance in acidic electrolytes but had minimal impact on the performance in alkaline electrolytes. By experimentally demonstrating that Ni
3
S
2
, metallic Ni, and N-doped carbon species were not the source of activity, we postulate that atomically dispersed Ni–N
x
/C sites are responsible for the ORR performance in acidic electrolytes, with an activity of −0.3 mA cm
–2
and a H
2
O
2
selectivity of 43% measured for the best Ni–N–C catalyst at 0.5 V vs RHE. This work highlights the potential and generates scientific insight into Ni–N–C catalysts to guide the design of improved performance metal–nitrogen–carbon catalysts based on inexpensive precursors and simplistic syntheses.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
) is among the top 100 most important industrial chemicals
(1,2)
used for a variety of applications, including pulp and textile bleaching, chemical synthesis, detoxification, and water treatment.
(3−7)
Particularly, H
2
O
2
can produce highly reactive oxidants (
•
OH) through activation by Fe(II) or UV processes for both oxidation of micropollutants and disinfection in water. H
2
O
2
is industrially produced by a batch multistep anthraquinone process which currently accounts for more than 95% of global production.
(5,8−10)
The complex extraction and separation steps, as well as the need for large-scale equipment, organic solvents, stabilizers, and expensive transportation due to the high reactivity of H
2
O
2
, have given motivation for the development of alternative methods for decentralized H
2
O
2
production.
(10,11)
As alternative methods for H
2
O
2
production, direct synthesis,
(11−17)
photocatalytic production,
(18−25)
and electrochemical production
(4,20,26−36)
have been suggested. Among them, the electrochemical production of H
2
O
2
via the two-electron (2e
–
) oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is attractive as it employs environmentally abundant reactants (i.e., oxygen) under near-ambient conditions that can be ideally coupled with renewable sources of electricity to achieve decentralized production of H
2
O
2
.
(17,37)
To improve the performance and lower the cost for electrochemical production of H
2
O
2
, the development of highly active, selective, and stable catalysts for the 2e
–
ORR remains a scientific challenge, as many electrode materials favor the competing 4e
–
ORR pathway that leads to the production of water.
(38−41)
While the 4e
–
reaction is important within the context of fuel cells as it affords the maximum power output, for the production of H
2
O
2
it is an undesirable competing reaction that results in reduced efficiency.

The activity and selectivity of a catalyst toward the production of H
2
O
2
is dictated by the surface-binding energy with the single intermediate species (OOH*, where * indicates an adsorbed species) involved in the 2e
–
ORR. For a catalyst to be selective toward H
2
O
2
, the catalyst must undergo associative adsorption of O
2
and retain the O–O bond during the ORR.
(6,42,43)
Electrocatalysts for the electrochemical production of H
2
O
2
from the 2e
–
ORR are conventionally based on noble metal alloys. Particularly, Pt or Pd alloys with metals such as Hg or Au have been demonstrated as promising catalysts with high activity and selectivity toward H
2
O
2
by tuning the catalyst-binding energies with the reactive intermediate OOH* (electronic effect) or by providing ensemble effects that enable the preservation of the O–O bond.
(10,16,38)
However, it is desirable to avoid the use of Hg due to its toxicity and to minimize the use of platinum group metals due to their high cost and intrinsic selectivity toward the 4e
–
ORR if the formation of Pt (or Pd) clusters cannot be avoided.
(35,44−47)
These challenges have shifted the direction of research toward platinum group metal-free ORR catalyst. To this end, nitrogen-doped carbon materials have been intensively investigated as low-cost ORR catalyst alternatives that are straightforward to prepare from inexpensive precursors.
(31,44,45,48−50)

Nitrogen-doped carbon materials
(31,44,48,49,51,52)
with a small amount of transition metal species (i.e., ∼1 wt % of Ni, Co, Mn, Fe, etc.), known as atomically dispersed metal–nitrogen–carbon (M–N–C) catalysts, have shown some promise for the electrochemical reduction of oxygen into H
2
O
2
. In particular, with the hypothesis being that the active site in M–N–C catalysts is a single, atomically dispersed transition metal ion coordinated by N/C-containing ligands, this is an isolated active site structure with the possibility to associatively adsorb O
2
molecules and preserve the O–O bond during the ORR.
(10,29,37,53−55)
Furthermore, the appropriate choice of transition metal type and synthesis method provides opportunity to tune the binding energies between the active site structures and reactive intermediates and to maximize the surface concentration of the catalytically active sites (e.g., M–N
x
).
(13,56−58)
In a recent study by Gao et al.,
(58)
Co–N–C was reported as the most active and selective catalyst for the production of H
2
O
2
in acidic media over the other M–N–C (M = Mn, Fe, Ni, and Cu) catalysts. Although Co–N–C has been identified as the most active candidate for the electrochemical production of H
2
O
2
in some studies, this contradicts previous literature that has identified Co–N–C catalysts as very active for the 4e
–
ORR in fuel cells,
(59)
indicating there may be challenges maintaining high 2e
–
selectivity when integrating these catalysts into high-loading three-dimensional electrodes. Meanwhile, Ni–N–C was found to be the second most active M–N–C catalyst for the production of H
2
O
2
.
(44)
Ni has the additional advantage of being three times less expensive than Co. Nevertheless, studies on Ni–N–C materials as ORR catalysts for the production of H
2
O
2
are limited in comparison to the number of Ni–N–C catalyst studies for electrochemical CO
2
reduction reactions.
(60,61)
In addition, the structure and properties of active sites in Ni–N–C materials for the production of H
2
O
2
at different pH electrolytes have not been rigorously investigated.

In this work, we examine the electrochemical activity and selectivity of Ni–N–C catalysts toward H
2
O
2
production in acidic and alkaline electrolytes by varying the Ni content of Ni–N–C catalysts. Ni–N–C catalysts were prepared by pyrolyzing, acid leaching, and repyrolyzing a mixture of nickel(II) chloride, polyaniline (PANI), and cyanamide (CM). This synthetic approach was adopted from a previous study for the preparation of Fe–N–C catalysts,
(40)
whereby PANI and CM precursors were deliberately mixed to prepare highly active catalysts with porosity resulting from the relatively low decomposition temperature of CM in comparison to PANI. The physicochemical properties of the Ni–N–C catalysts were characterized and correlated to the electrocatalytic performance to understand the properties underlying the activity and selectivity toward H
2
O
2
. Particularly, the resulting materials were heterogeneous in nature, consisting of a variety of different species including nitrogen-doped carbon sites, Ni–N
x
/C sites, Ni particles, and Ni–sulfide particles. We conducted a series of experiments to understand the structure and properties of different active sites in Ni–N–C catalysts at play in different pH electrolytes, including benchmarking experiments to understand the role of the various chemical species present in the catalyst structure. This work provides insight toward the synthesis, characterization, and mechanistic understanding of Ni–N–C electrocatalysts prepared by simple techniques for the electrochemical production of H
2
O
2
from oxygen and can provide information about the design of improved performance M–N–C catalysts for oxygen reduction.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
One milliliter of aniline (ACS reagent, 99.5% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to 200 mL of a 1.5 M hydrochloric acid solution (ACS reagent, 27%) and stirred by a magnetic bar at room temperature on a stir plate, followed by the addition 2.0 g of cyanamide (99% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) and varying amounts of nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (99.9% trace metal basis, Sigma-Aldrich). In particular, 0.08, 0.30, or 1.20 g of Ni(II)Cl was added for the synthesis of Ni–N–C-low, Ni–N-medium, and Ni–N-high, respectively. Once NiCl
2
was dissolved, 1.5 g of ammonium persulfate (ACS reagent, 98% purity, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to the solution as an oxidant to catalyze the oxidative polymerization of aniline. The solution was stirred with a magnetic stir bar at 600 r.p.m. at room temperature for 2 h to allow full polymerization of aniline, and then the liquid was evaporated by heating the hot plate to 80 °C while stirring at 200 r.p.m. until it became tarlike (approximately 12 h). The collected material was subsequently heat treated at 900 °C in an argon atmosphere (Ultra High Purity, Praxair) for 1 h inside a tube furnace (Thermo Scientific Lindberg/Blue M TF55030A-1). The resultant powder was ground and crushed using a mortar and pestle and was then mixed with 100 mL of a 0.5 M sulfuric acid solution (ACS reagent, 95.0–98.0% Sigma-Aldrich) and sonicated for 10 min to obtain a well-dispersed solution. This solution was then stirred at 800 r.p.m. on a hot plate set at 90 °C for 6 h to leach out any acid-soluble nanoparticles or residues. The resulting solution was then vacuum filtered and washed. The recovered powder was collected and dried in an oven at 90 °C for 12 h. The dried power was pyrolyzed again at 900 °C in an argon atmosphere for 3 h to obtain the final catalyst. A metal-free catalyst (N–C) was prepared using the exact same procedure as the Ni–N–C catalysts except that no Ni salt was added during the synthesis, and hence the steps after the first pyrolysis were not performed as there was no need for acid leaching, drying, and a second pyrolysis. Therefore, the final powder was collected right after the first pyrolysis.

Field-emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution image-corrected transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images along with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were obtained on an FEI Titan 80-300 LB instrument operating at 300 keV at the Canadian Centre of Electron Microscopy (CCEM) to determine the morphological and structural characterization of the catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were acquired using a FEI Magellan 400 with subnanometer resolution. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with Cu Kα radiation ranging from 5° to 95° at the McMaster Analytical X-ray Diffraction Facility (MAX). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on on a PHI Quantera II Scanning XPS Microprobe at the Biointerfaces Institute at McMaster University.

The electrochemical H
2
O
2
production was performed in a conventional three-electrode cell with a rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) setup connected to a Bio-Logic VSP-300 Multipotentiostat system (
Figure S1
), using a graphite rod and Ag/AgCl for counter and reference electrodes, respectively. The RRDE electrode (Pine Research Instrumentation, Inc.) consisted of a 5 mm diameter glassy carbon disk electrode of geometric area 0.196 35 cm
2
that was cleaned and well-polished according to
Note S1
and a platinum ring electrode of 55 mm inner and 65 mm outer diameters. Catalyst-coated glassy carbon electrodes were used as the working electrode.

Catalyst-coated electrodes were prepared through an ink-based spin-coating process to achieve uniform electrode coverage. The inks were formulated by mixing synthesized catalysts (3.0 mg) in 750 μL of isopropyl alcohol (ACS reagent, 99.5% purity, Sigma-Aldrich), followed by a ultrasonication for 20 min to produce homogeneous, uniform, and well-dispersed inks. A 3.27 μL aliquot of the catalyst ink was then drop-casted in three intervals to get a total of 9.8 μL of ink deposited onto the tip of a well-polished glassy carbon disk electrode of the RRDE spinning at an initial rate of 150 rpm, which was increased to 400 rpm, followed by the deposition of 15 μL of a dilute Nafion solution prepared from mixing 200 μL of Nafion (Sigma-Aldrich, 5 wt % Nafion in ethanol) in 19 mL of isopropyl alcohol and drying at room temperature. The final electrode–catalyst loading was 0.2 mg cm
–2
.

All the potentials were measured versus the Ag/AgCl electrode and then converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale as depicted in
Figure S2
. The calibration of the potential scale is described in the Supporting Information (
Note S2
). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out by sweeping the disk potential between 0 and 1 V vs RHE at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
while holding the Pt ring at 1.2 V vs RHE to oxidize the H
2
O
2
species generated on the disk electrode for the quantification of H
2
O
2
. Two electrolytes with pH ∼ 1 (0.1 M HClO
4
) and pH ∼ 13 (0.1 M KOH) were used at room temperature. The electrolytes were initially purged with nitrogen gas or oxygen gas for 30 min before electrochemical measurements to reach saturation. Prior to the ORR measurement, precycling steps were conducted for electrochemical cleaning, where the platinum ring electrode was initially cycled from 0.0 to 1.2 V vs RHE for 500 cycles at a scan rate of 500 mV s
–1
in a nitrogen-saturated electrolyte until a stable steady state cyclic voltammogram shape was attained. The ORR activity was determined by subtracting the background current obtained in a nitrogen-saturated electrolyte from that obtained in an oxygen-saturated electrolyte according to eq 1 (
Note S3
).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The as-synthesized metal-free N–C, Ni–N–C-low, Ni–N–C-medium, and Ni–N–C-high catalysts were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). All four catalysts showed similar structures by SEM as depicted in
Figure
1
, indicating that the overall nanostructure is relatively insensitive to changes in Ni content. The samples revealed a morphology consisting of hierarchical pore structures that can be considered desirable for catalytic applications due to improved mass transport. Interestingly, fiberlike structures were observed in both Ni–N–C-medium and Ni–N–C-high catalysts as indicated by the red arrows in
Figure
1
c and d. This likely arises from the ability of Ni to catalyze the formation of carbon nanotubes from carbonaceous precursors at the pyrolysis temperature of 900 °C used during catalyst synthesis.
(62−64)

div.p: Figure 1. SEM images of (a) N–C, (b) Ni–N–C-low, (c) Ni–N–C medium, and (d) Ni–N–C-high catalysts, with the red arrows indicating the presence of fiberlike structures.

div.div:
To further investigate the effect of Ni loading on catalyst structures, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was conducted.
Figure
2
and
Figure S3
show TEM images at different resolutions where the overall morphology of the main structures including fibrous carbon particles (primary phase) and layers of porous carbon sheets (secondary phase) are observed in the nickel-containing samples. For all of the Ni–N–C catalysts, dark spots with polydisperse size distributions were observed throughout the catalyst structures, indicating the formation of nickel-containing particles during materials synthesis.

div.p: Figure 2. Low- and high-magnification HRTEM results of (a, e) N–C, (b, f) Ni–N–C-low, (c, g) medium, and (d, h) high catalysts.

div.div:
Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were conducted (
Figure
3
a). The results of EDS mapping shows bright regions in all three Ni-containing catalysts, confirming the presence of Ni-containing particles that are bright due to their high Z-contrast compared to neighboring light elements such as C or O. It should also be noted that the Ni signal was observed distributed throughout all regions of the catalyst structure, potentially indicating the formation of atomically dispersed Ni–N–C sites within the carbon framework.

div.p: Figure 3. (a) STEM-HAADF and EDS maps for C, O, S, and Ni and (b) X-ray diffraction pattern of N–C, Ni–N–C-low, Ni–N–C-medium, and Ni–N–C-high catalysts.

div.div:
It is worth to note that sulfur was found in all materials due to the presence of ammonium persulfate during the synthesis procedure. In all materials, EDS maps show a homogeneous distribution of carbon, oxygen, and sulfur, with the elemental compositions from highest to lowest in Ni–N–C samples being carbon, oxygen, nickel, and sulfur. The exact elemental compositions of all catalyst samples are presented in
Table S1
. Nitrogen was not detected by EDS owing to the limitations of this technique; however, a more detailed analysis on the near-surface elemental compositions of the samples is presented later in the paper using XPS analysis which includes interrogation of the nitrogen species present in the materials.

Having observed and confirmed the presence of nanoparticles by the aid of electron microscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was then performed to probe the crystalline structures present in the samples (
Figure
3
b). The XRD pattern of the N–C catalyst shows a broad carbon peak centered at ca. 22° that is attributed to graphitic carbon, with its broadness resulting from the amorphous nature of its structure. All three Ni-containing samples exhibit a similar broad diffraction peak at 26°, which can be assigned to the (002) plane of a graphitic carbon, indicating that 900 °C was sufficient to form some degree of graphitization in our materials. In addition, intense diffraction peaks were exhibited in all three Ni-containing catalysts corresponding to metallic Ni and Ni
3
S
2
(JCPDS no. 44-1418), although the peaks for Ni
3
S
2
were relatively small compared to those of metallic Ni, indicating smaller crystallite sizes. It is interesting to observe metallic nickel in the samples, as removal would be expected during the acid-leaching process employed during catalyst synthesis. Therefore, these metallic Ni particles are embedded within a protective graphitic shell that prevents their dissolution,
(61,65)
and their removal would require more aggressive techniques to penetrate the protective coating, which would likely have adverse effects on the catalyst structures. However, as these Ni nanoparticles are coated, they would not contribute to catalysis as this is a surface-based process, and the protective shell around them hinders electrolyte/reactant access during electrochemical ORR testing. The presence of Ni
3
S
2
phase species was also revealed by XRD (
Figure
3
b), which was used to investigate the acid stability (0.5 M sulfuric acid at 90 °C) of Ni
3
S
2
species to determine if they would survive the acid-leaching procedure used during synthesis or were potentially protected by a graphitic carbon shell similar to the Ni metal nanoparticles. We evaluated the solubility of Ni
3
S
2
in acids using commercial Ni
3
S
2
powders (
Note S4
), and they were found to survive an acid-washing procedure. These results indicate that the Ni
3
S
2
species in our catalyst are likely exposed to the electrolyte/reactants during electrochemical testing, and therefore we conducted benchmarking experiments to investigate their impact on ORR performance (
vide infra
).

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to identify near-surface elemental compositions and chemical structures present in the synthesized catalysts. The chemical compositions of the N–C, Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high catalysts determined from the survey spectra (
Figure
4
a) are summarized in
Table S2
. High-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p3, C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, and S 2p of N–C, Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high catalysts are shown in
Figure S4
. Based on the XPS quantification, the content of Ni increased with the increase in Ni concentration present during the synthesis from 1.2 atom % for Ni–N–C-low to 1.5 atom % for Ni–N–C-high. All four catalysts exhibited a near-surface nitrogen concentration of >8 atom %. Particularly, the metal-free catalyst exhibited the highest concentration of nitrogen of ca. 11.6 atom % as compared to that of the Ni-containing catalysts (9.5, 8.3, and 8.3 atom % for Ni–N–C-low, Ni–N–C-medium, and Ni–N–C-high, respectively). To gain further insight into the chemical structure of the nitrogen species, high-resolution XPS analysis of the N 1s region was performed (
Figure
4
b). The N 1s spectra of the N–C and Ni–N–C catalysts were deconvoluted into three peaks: 398.2–398.9, 400.8–400.9, and 402.5–403.1 eV, which are attributed to pyridinic, pyrrolic/graphitic (difficult to deconvolute these two species due to similar binding energies), and oxidized nitrogen species, respectively.
(61,66)
A summary of the different types of nitrogen groups at the near-surface is summarized in
Table S3
. The fraction of pyridinic nitrogen relative to the total nitrogen content increased with increasing addition of Ni, from 41% for Ni–N–C-low to 44% for Ni–N–C-high. This result suggests that Ni dopant atoms facilitate the formation of pyridinic nitrogen sites which can potentially coordinate Ni in a Ni–N–C configuration. This shift in the distribution of various nitrogen species highlights the role nickel plays in tuning the type of nitrogen present, which is likely due to the formation of nitrogen-coordinated Ni species, whereby theoretical calculations have indicated that the binding energy between Ni atoms and fourfold pyridinic sites can be as high as 8 eV.
(67)

div.p: Figure 4. (a) Survey XPS spectra of N–C, Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high catalysts; (b) deconvolution of the high-resolution XPS spectra of N 1s of N–C, Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high catalysts.

div.h3: 3.2. Electrochemical Performance of Ni–N–C Catalysts in Acidic Electrolytes
div.div:
RRDE voltammetry was used to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of N–C and Ni–N–C catalysts.
Figure S5
shows the CV curves of all four catalysts obtained in oxygen- and nitrogen-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte. The normalized (to geometric electrode surface area) and background-corrected linear sweep voltammograms of N–C, Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high catalysts obtained in oxygen-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
are shown in
Figure
5
a. For the disk current density, the onset potential (the potential at which a current density of 0.1 mA cm
–2
is achieved) of N–C catalyst was 0.23 V vs RHE. Meanwhile, Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high exhibited a much higher onset potential at 0.58, 0.59, and 0.64 V vs RHE, respectively, indicating that Ni plays an important role in improving the activity of the catalyst for the ORR. Furthermore, the similar onset potentials observed for Ni–N–C-low, medium, and high catalysts suggest the presence of similarly structured active sites within the catalysts. The current density and thereby catalytic activity toward the ORR increased with an increase in contents of Ni from −0.18 mA cm
–2
for Ni–N–C-low to −0.21 mA cm
–2
for Ni–N–C-medium and −0.31 mA cm
–2
for Ni–N–C-high at 0.5 V vs RHE (
Figure
5
a). At this potential the N–C catalyst did not produce any Faradaic ORR current, which is consistent with previous reports on the important role of metals in providing catalytic activity for nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts in acidic media.
(68)

div.p:
Figure 5. RRDE results for ORR on N–C and Ni–N–C catalysts containing different Ni concentrations. (a) O
2
reduction current densities obtained from the disk electrode, (b) ring currents collected on the Pt ring at a constant potential of 1.2 V
RHE
, and (c) calculated selectivity of catalysts for the reduction of O
2
to H
2
O
2
. The experiments were performed at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
, using a catalyst loading of 0.2 mg cm
–2
on the RRDE tip and a 0.1 M HClO
4
electrolyte, at room temperature and ambient pressure.

div.div:
The electrochemical accessible surface area (ECSA) is an important parameter as it is generally proportional to the number of active sites available for the ORR. Background CVs were used to determine the ECSA of the materials by calculating the double-layer capacitance. The ECSA of each sample was ultimately calculated by dividing the capacitance obtained from the integration of the background electrical double-layer current by literature-established specific capacitance values of carbon-based materials (0.015 mF cm
–2
)
(69,70)
according to eq 2 in
Note S3
of the Supporting Information. ECSA values of the catalysts increased with the presence of Ni during synthesis, from 35.4 m
2
g
–1
for N–C to 352 m
2
g
–1
for Ni–N–C-low. Further increases in ECSA were observed at higher Ni contents, with an ECSA of 459 m
2
g
–1
for Ni–N–C-medium and 464 m
2
g
–1
for Ni–N–C-high measured.

Ring currents collected on the platinum ring electrode at a constant potential of 1.2 V vs RHE along with their calculated corresponding yields of H
2
O
2
based on eq 3 (
Note S3
) are shown in
Figure
5
b and c, respectively, which provides information about the selectivity of these catalyst materials toward the 2e
–
ORR. As a rule of thumb, all selectivity data in this paper are reported for disk potential values where the disk current density and ring current are greater than 0.1 mA cm
–2
and 0.4 μA, respectively. Anything below these threshold values is not reported as the data are impacted by noise and capacitance. The number of electrons transferred was also calculated using eq 4 (
Note S3
) and is shown in
Figure S6
. As
Figure
5
c demonstrates, the selectivity toward the 2e
−
ORR increased with Ni content, with Ni–N–C-high showing the highest selectivity of 43% H
2
O
2
at a potential of 0.5 V vs RHE (i.e., at a low overpotential) which meets one of the important challenges faced by the M–N–C catalysts since the promotion of the ORR commonly only happens at high overpotentials in acid media. This selectivity is not as high as the 93% H
2
O
2
selectivity obtained by Co–N–C (0.59 V vs RHE) or 82% H
2
O
2
selectivity for other Ni–N–C at a much lower electrode potential of 0.2 V vs RHE reported in the literature.
(58,71)
For this previously reported Ni–N–C catalyst,
(58)
it is important to note that the electrode loadings used were approximately 1 order of magnitude lower than those used in our study (0.025 versus 0.2 mg/cm
2
, respectively), whereby lower electrode loadings have been shown to produce significantly higher amounts of H
2
O
2
,
(72−74)
although they are likely not reflective of loadings that would be used in a practical electrode structure. Thereby, the results of the present study show the promise of Ni–M–C catalysts to achieve high activity at low overpotentials that are more practical from an energy efficiency standpoint in acidic electrolytes as our Ni–N–C catalysts employ an inexpensive transition metal (Ni) that is much cheaper than cobalt and utilize a simple preparation process, thereby warranting further investigation and optimization.

Collectively, the obtained results indicate that the active sites in an acidic electrolyte (0.1 M HClO
4
) contributing to the significant improvement in activity of Ni–N–C catalysts compared to N–C catalysts arise due the presence of Ni during the catalyst synthesis. We therefore postulate that there are three potential classes of active site structures present in these materials: (1) atomically dispersed nickel ions coordinated with nitrogen that are embedded throughout the Ni–N–C structure as reported previously for materials prepared by pyrolyzing a mixture of nickel, nitrogen, and carbon precursors;
(61,75−77)
(2) metallic Ni particles; or (3) Ni
3
S
2
particles present in the catalyst that have been previously shown to be capable of facilitating the ORR in neutral media.
(78)
We are able to rule out the contributions of Ni particles to ORR activity, as any of the only Ni particles that would have survived the acid-leaching process used during catalyst synthesis would have been removed, and therefore these particles are completely covered by layers of graphitic carbon and are not accessible for catalysis. To investigate the potential impact of Ni
3
S
2
, we performed benchmarking experiments (
vide infra
) that enabled us to experimentally rule out significant contributions from Ni
3
S
2
to the activity of the Ni–N–C catalysts. Therefore, we speculate that atomically dispersed Ni–N–C sites are responsible for the activity and selectivity observed in acidic electrolytes. With higher Ni contents present during synthesis, a higher number of these active site structures could be formed due to both the higher surface area supported by ECSA measurements and the higher amount of Ni available for coordination.

div.h3: 3.3. Active Sites of Ni–N–C Catalysts in Different pH Electrolytes
div.div:
Although the performance of electrocatalysts in acidic electrolytes is more critical as compared to that in alkaline electrolytes for practical implications due to the instability of HO
2
–
in alkaline conditions, the alkaline study was also conducted to gain insight into the active site structures present in these materials. We investigated the ORR activity and selectivity in an alkaline electrolyte (0.1 M KOH) and compared the results with that in an acidic electrolyte (0.1 M HClO
4
) for N–C and Ni–N–C-medium catalysts shown in
Figure
6
as the identity of active site structures for the ORR can vary depending on the pH of the electrolyte. The equilibrium potential comparison of the ORR reaction pathways in acid and alkaline electrolytes is given in
Note S5
. The Ni–N–C-medium shows a higher disk current density and ring current than N–C in alkaline media. Overall, both N–C and Ni–N–C-medium catalysts showed significantly higher disk current densities (−1.1 and −1.3 mA cm
–2
for N–C and Ni–N–C-medium catalysts at 0.5 V vs RHE, respectively) than those in the acidic electrolyte, where the Ni–N–C-medium shows a current density of −0.2 mA cm
–2
whereas the N–C catalyst shows no appreciable activity at 0.5 V vs RHE. In addition, the ring current as well as the % H
2
O
2
were also higher in alkaline media having a % H
2
O
2
of 87% and 76% for N–C and Ni–N–C medium catalysts, respectively, in an alkaline electrolyte at 0.58 V vs RHE, which was relatively constant over the entire potential range investigated. This is in contrast to that in acidic electrolytes where Ni–N–C-medium catalysts showed a selectivity of 36% at 0.5 V vs RHE, which decreased at lower electrode potentials, whereas N–C showed no appreciable ORR activity until 0.23 V vs RHE and no H
2
O
2
production until 0.20 V vs RHE. These results show much higher ORR performance of the catalysts in alkaline electrolytes as compared to that in acidic electrolytes in terms of both activity and selectivity toward H
2
O
2
. This is likely due to the more facile ORR kinetics in alkaline media in comparison to acidic media.
(79,80)

div.p:
Figure 6. RRDE results for ORR on N–C and Ni–N–C-medium catalysts in two different electrolytes of 0.1 M HClO
4
and 0.1 M KOH: (a) O
2
reduction current densities obtained from the disk electrode, (b) ring currents collected on the Pt ring at a constant potential of 1.2 V
RHE
, and (c) calculated selectivity of catalysts for the reduction of O
2
to H
2
O
2
The experiments were performed at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
, using a catalyst loading of 0.2 mg cm
–2
on the RRDE tip at room temperature and ambient pressure.

div.div:
It is noteworthy that the ORR performance of N–C and Ni–N–C-medium catalysts in alkaline electrolytes exhibited only minor differences in contrast to those observed in acidic electrolytes (
Figure
6
). In addition, the ORR results of N–C and Ni–N–C low, medium, and high catalysts obtained in alkaline electrolytes also showed only marginal differences (
Figure S7
). These results indicate that different active site structures are likely at play in alkaline electrolytes, potentially consisting of nitrogen-doped carbon sites that have been shown to be capable of facilitating the ORR in alkaline media but not in acidic media.
(52)

The next step was to evaluate the impact that Ni
3
S
2
particles may have on the ORR performance of the Ni–N–C catalysts. To investigate the potential contributions of Ni
3
S
2
species, we conducted ORR measurements in both acidic (
Figure
7
a–c) and alkaline electrolytes (
Figure
7
d–f) on commercial Ni
3
S
2
particles that were mixed with Vulcan XC-72 carbon black (C–Ni
3
S
2
/VC). To provide more direct comparison, we also subjected the commercial Ni
3
S
2
to the same procedures used during the synthesis of the Ni–N–C catalysts (to expose the commercial Ni
3
S
2
particles to what the Ni
3
S
2
particles in the Ni–N–C catalysts were exposed to) by acid treating and pyrolyzing the Ni
3
S
2
/VC materials (denoted as P–Ni
3
S
2
/VC) and tested their ORR activity (detailed synthesis procedure of these catalysts is described in
Note S4
). Additionally, ORR measurements on pure Vulcan XC-72 powder (VC) are also shown. In an acidic electrolyte (
Figure
7
a–c) the commercial Ni
3
S
2
-containing samples showed no appreciable activity at potentials above ca. 0.3 V vs RHE, suggesting that these species do not provide significant contributions to the activity of Ni–N–C catalysts in acidic electrolytes. However, in an alkaline electrolyte (
Figure
7
d–f), the commercial Ni
3
S
2
samples in addition to the pure VC show considerable activity for the ORR and selectivity toward H
2
O
2
, indicating they likely provide contributions to the alkaline-based ORR performance of Ni–N–C and further providing evidence for the more facile ORR kinetics in alkaline media that can occur on a variety of different (including metal-free) active site structures.

div.p:
Figure 7. RRDE results for the ORR on Vulcan carbon (VC), pyrolyzed Ni
3
S
2
/VC, and commercial Ni
3
S
2
/VC nanopowders in two different electrolytes of 0.1 M HClO
4
(a–c) and 0.1 M KOH (d–f): (a, d) O
2
reduction current densities obtained from the disk electrode, (b, e) ring currents collected on the Pt ring at a constant potential of 1.2 V
RHE
, and (c, f) calculated selectivity of catalysts for the reduction of O
2
to H
2
O
2
. The experiments were performed at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
, using a loading of 0.2 mg cm
–2
on the RRDE tip at room temperature and ambient pressure.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Herein we report the results of a systematic study correlating the physicochemical properties and amount of Ni precursors used to prepare Ni–N–C catalyst materials toward their electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for the ORR in both acidic (0.1 M HClO
4
) and alkaline (0.1 M KOH) electrolytes. We demonstrated the importance of adding Ni during catalyst synthesis by comparing the activity of Ni–N–C versus (Ni-free) N–C catalysts in acidic media, whereby the latter demonstrated negligible activity. The Ni–N–C catalysts were found to contain metallic Ni and Ni
3
S
2
particles in their structure. Metallic Ni was determined to have no impact on catalysis, as metallic Ni particles were covered by a protective shell that prevented their removal during the acid-leaching step used during catalyst synthesis and by extension also prevented reactant/electrolyte access during ORR testing. We conducted benchmarking experiments to evaluate the potential impact that the Ni
3
S
2
particles present in the Ni–N–C catalysts had on the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity by evaluating the electrochemical performance of commercial Ni
3
S
2
particles mixed with carbon black. In acidic electrolytes, the Ni
3
S
2
species were found to have negligible impact on the ORR activity, and therefore we postulate that the presence of Ni precursors during catalyst synthesis resulted in the formation of atomically dispersed Ni–N
x
/C active site structures capable of facilitating the ORR. In alkaline media, whereby the ORR is a more facile process, various active site structures are likely at play including Ni–N
x
/C active sites, Ni
3
S
2
particles, and nitrogen-doped carbon sites present in the carbon matrix of the catalyst structure. For the ORR in acidic media that is advantageous for the distributed production of H
2
O
2
, the best Ni–N–C catalyst in this work was able to achieve a selectivity of 43% H
2
O
2
at a potential of 0.5 V vs RHE. While this leaves an opportunity for improvement, Ni–N–C catalysts employ an inexpensive transition metal (Ni) and a simple preparation process that warrant further investigations. While our experimental evidence and support from the literature points toward atomically dispersed Ni–N
x
/C species as the likely active sites in Ni–N–C catalysts for the ORR in acidic media, future work should include advanced (ideally
in situ
) characterization techniques and/or investigations of model compounds to pinpoint the exact configuration of these Ni–N
x
/C active structures that will provide design criteria to guide the development of improved activity and selectivity catalysts. Furthermore, identifying the mechanisms that dictate activity and selectivity, such as whether different active site structures on these Ni–N–C catalysts are leading to an indirect 4e
–
ORR process or H
2
O
2
disproportionation in the electrode structures, can provide valuable insight in terms of future catalyst designs. This work provides a rigorous investigation and systematic insight into the synthesis–structure–property–performance relationships of Ni–N–C catalysts that can be used to guide these further studies aimed at producing inexpensive catalyst materials with high activity and selectivity for the reduction of oxygen into H
2
O
2
.

A review of processes of prodn. of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is widely used in almost all industrial areas, particularly in the chem. industry and environmental protection. The only degrdn. product of its use is water, and thus it has played a large role in environmentally friendly methods in the chem. industry. Hydrogen peroxide is produced on an industrial scale by the anthraquinone oxidn. process. However, this process can hardly be considered a green method. It involves the sequential hydrogenation and oxidn. of an alkylanthraquinone precursor dissolved in a mixt. of org. solvents followed by liq.-liq. extn. to recover H2O2. The anthraquinone oxidn. process is a multistep method that requires significant energy input and generates waste, which has a neg. effect on its sustainability and prodn. costs. The transport, storage, and handling of bulk H2O2 involve hazards and escalating expenses. Thus, novel, cleaner methods for the prodn. of H2O2 are being explored. The direct synthesis of H2O2 from O2 and H2 using a variety of catalysts, and the factors influencing the formation and decompn. of H2O2 are examd.

Defective Carbon-Based Materials for the Electrochemical Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide
Chen, Shucheng; Chen, Zhihua; Siahrostami, Samira; Kim, Taeho Roy; Nordlund, Dennis; Sokaras, Dimosthenis; Nowak, Stanislaw; To, John W. F.; Higgins, Drew; Sinclair, Robert; Noerskov, Jens K.; Jaramillo, Thomas F.; Bao, Zhenan

Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), an important industrial chem., is currently produced through an energy-intensive anthraquinone process that is limited to large-scale facilities. Small-scale decentralized electrochem. prodn. of H2O2 via a two-electron oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) offers unique opportunities for sanitization applications and the purifn. of drinking water. The development of inexpensive, efficient, and selective catalysts for this reaction remains a challenge. Herein, we examine two different porous carbon-based electrocatalysts and show that they exhibit high selectivity for H2O2 under alk. conditions. By rationally varying synthetic methods, we explore the effect of pore size on electrocatalytic performance. Furthermore, by means of d. functional calcns., we point out the crit. role of carbon defects. Our theory results show that the majority of defects in graphene are naturally selective for the two-electron redn. of O2 to H2O2, and we identify the types of defects with high activity.

H2O2 is a valuable, environmentally friendly oxidizing agent with a wide range of uses from the provision of clean H2O to the synthesis of valuable chems. The on-site electrolytic prodn. of H2O2 would bring the chem. to applications beyond its present reach. The successful commercialization of electrochem. H2O2 prodn. requires cathode catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and stability. In this Perspective, the authors highlight the authors' current understanding of the factors that control the cathode performance. The authors review the influence of catalyst material, electrolyte, and the structure of the interface at the mesoscopic scale. The authors provide original theor. data on the role of the geometry of the active site and its influence on activity and selectivity. The authors have also conducted original expts. on (i) the effect of pH on H2O2 prodn. on glassy C, pure metals, and metal-Hg alloys, and (ii) the influence of cell geometry and mass transport in liq. half-cells in comparison to membrane electrode assemblies.

A review. From an economic perspective, textile and paper bleaching are amongst the most important oxidn. processes. The removal of unwanted chromophores, be it stains on cloths or residual lignin in wood pulp, consumes more than 60% of the world prodn. of hydrogen peroxide. However, existing technologies have their limitations. At ambient temp., hydrogen peroxide gives little stain bleaching and is used inefficiently. Hence the high product dosages and washing temps. required limit its application to predominantly European markets, to the exclusion of the majority of the world's population. In paper manuf., the use of chlorine-based oxidants results in the formation of chlorinated waste products, which show poor biodegradability. On the other hand, hydrogen peroxide requires higher temps., longer reaction times and is more expensive. Transition-metal catalysts offer an alternative. This review discusses the main classes of known bleach catalysts and their possible modes of action.

Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a highly efficient and green oxidant has become one of the 100 most important chems. in the world. Some current research progress in the direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 by noble-metal catalyst, fuel cell and plasma methods has been reviewed systematically in this paper. Perspectives about the development direction and application prospect of the above-mentioned three methods have also been discussed.

A review. Electrochem. prodn. of H2O2 from O2 is a promising alternative to the energy-intensive anthraquinone process that is currently used as an industry std. Although most research on the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) has focused on the 4-electron pathway to water relevant to fuel cells, the 2-electron ORR to produce H2O2 is also of significant com. interest. The first half of this Perspective deals with the progress made in developing noble metal, carbon-based, and single-atom electrocatalysts and highlights the design strategies employed to obtain high selectivity toward H2O2. The second half addresses the challenges of large-scale prodn. and how results obtained using a rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) can be translated into com. viable flow cells. This Perspective focuses on the design of catalysts and cells that will enable industrial-scale electrochem. H2O2 prodn.

H2O2 is a valuable, environmentally friendly oxidizing agent with a wide range of uses from the provision of clean H2O to the synthesis of valuable chems. The on-site electrolytic prodn. of H2O2 would bring the chem. to applications beyond its present reach. The successful commercialization of electrochem. In this Perspective, the authors highlight the authors' current understanding of the factors that control the cathode performance. The authors review the influence of catalyst material, electrolyte, and the structure of the interface at the mesoscopic scale. The authors provide original theor. data on the role of the geometry of the active site and its influence on activity and selectivity. The authors have also conducted original expts. on (i) the effect of pH on H2O2 prodn. on glassy C, pure metals, and metal-Hg alloys, and (ii) the influence of cell geometry and mass transport in liq. half-cells in comparison to membrane electrode assemblies.

Hydrogen peroxide is a 'green' oxidant whose relatively high cost has prevented it from being applied to commodity chem. processing. In large part, those attributes of the current process (the anthraquinone route) that contribute to the cost of H2O2 also contribute to its non-sustainable features; byproduct streams, energy input, and multiple required unit operations. We have explored the generation of hydrogen peroxide directly from hydrogen and oxygen using liq. CO2 as the solvent and a CO2-sol. palladium catalyst. Producing H2O2 directly from H2 and O2 eliminates unit operations and reduces raw material costs significantly. Further, homogeneous reaction in liq. CO2 allows for contact between significant concns. of O2 and H2, high rate of reaction, and ready recovery of the product via stripping into water. Both Pd(II) and Pd(0) catalysts were explored for the reaction; our results suggest that future work should focus on optimization of a CO2-sol. or dispersible Pd(0) catalyst.

Acidic niobia-silica (NbS, 4-14 wt % Nb) materials used as supports of dispersed Pd particles (1.0-2.0 wt % Pd) have been prepd. from different Nb-precursors (niobium ethoxide, NBE, and ammonium niobium oxalate, ANBO) and techniques (copptn. and deposition), characterized, and tested in the direct synthesis of H2O2 in water and methanol solvents. In particular, on a typical NbS sample, the evolution of morphol. (by N2-adsorption-desorption), cryst.-phase (by XRD), electronic structure (by UV-vis-DRS), and surface acidity with time/temp. of treatment (350-800 °C for 4-100 h) has been investigated. Surface acidity was measured by titrns. with 2-phenylethylamine adsorption in various liqs.: cyclohexane, for the intrinsic acidity, and water, methanol, and water-methanol mixts. for the effective acidities. Direct H2O2 synthesis reaction was performed in semi-batch slurry reactor with continuous feeding of the gaseous mixt. (H2, O2, and N2), under pressure (5 × 103 kPa or 104 kPa) at 5 °C in methanol or in water. In both solvents, reaction rates only little decreased with time on stream, ca. 5% of rate decrease after 4 h of reaction from initial rate of ca. 0.5 gH2O2·(kgsolution·min)-1, according with the slight Pd sintering obsd. by TEM images. Catalysts prepd. by deposition of NBE on silica gave better performances than those prepd. from ANBO. In general, selectivity to H2O2 in water and in methanol was obsd. to be similar; the unexpected good selectivity in water was due to the higher effective acid strengths of the catalytic surfaces in water than in methanol, as exptl. proven.

Pd-based catalysts in which the Pd is alloyed with a transition metal (TM) are often considered for the direct synthesis of H2O2. In particular, PdAu and PdHg alloys are known for their good catalytic activities. However, finding suitable catalysts with designed compns. is not easy and the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms behind their enhanced activities is often lacking. In the current study, descriptor sets for direct H2O2 synthesis on Pd, PdAu, and PdHg surfaces were proposed based on d. functional theory. By considering the surface electronic effects caused by the alloy surface compn., descriptor sets consisting of the adsorption energy for reaction intermediates such as O2, O, and OOH and activation energy barriers were derived from elementary reaction steps. The geometric factors of the adsorbed species were also considered, but found to be less important. The adsorption energies of O2 and O were calcd. and compared to det. that surface-adsorbed O*2 is the intermediate species required to form the desired product. The selectivity was assessed by comparing the adsorption energies of O and OOH. Considering the main thermodn. and kinetic characteristics, the results showed that the PdHg alloy with a surface compn. having the at. ratio 2 : 1 gives the best selectivity. The results of the descriptor anal. indicated that alloying Pd with less active metals, such as Hg and Au, is a key strategy for designing catalysts with better catalytic activity and selectivity.

A review. H2O2 is important in large-scale industrial processes and smaller on-site activities. The present industrial route to H2O2 involves hydrogenation of an anthraquinone and O2 oxidn. of the resulting dihydroanthraquinone - a costly method and one that is impractical for routine on-site use. Electrosynthesis of H2O2 is cost-effective and applicable on both large and small scales. This Review describes methods to design and assess electrode materials for H2O2 electrosynthesis. H2O2 can be prepd. by oxidizing H2O at efficient anodic catalysts such as those based on BiVO4. Alternatively, H2O2 forms by partially reducing O2 at cathodes featuring either noble metal alloys or doped carbon. In addn. to the catalyst materials used, one must also consider the form and geometry of the electrodes and the type of reactor in order to strike a balance between properties such as mass transport and electroactive area, both of which substantially affect both the selectivity and rate of reaction. Research into catalyst materials and reactor designs is arguably quite mature, such that the future of H2O2 electrosynthesis will instead depend on the design of complete and efficient electrosynthesis systems, in which the complementary properties of the catalysts and the reactor lead to optimal selectivity and overall yield.

The direct synthesis of H2O2 (DSH) from H and O is an attractive prodn. route due to its green nature. However, it faces multiple tech. challenges, the biggest being the explosion risk of the flammable gas mixt. Herein we used microreactors to perform the reaction in an inherently safer way which allows the H concn. to fall within the explosion limit range. For the 1st time, we have studied the flame propagation phenomena inside a microreactor to det. the optimum channel dimension for DSH. A mechanism of fast synthesis and slow destruction has been proposed via study on the influence of channel length and liq. flow rate. Besides, a variety of reaction parameters including gas flow rate, O: H ratio, catalyst compn. and gas pressure have been studied carefully. The successful employment of a microreactor in this case indicated the potential of using microreactors to inhibit the explosion risks of hazardous processes.

A review of processes of prodn. of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is widely used in almost all industrial areas, particularly in the chem. industry and environmental protection. The only degrdn. product of its use is water, and thus it has played a large role in environmentally friendly methods in the chem. industry. Hydrogen peroxide is produced on an industrial scale by the anthraquinone oxidn. process. However, this process can hardly be considered a green method. It involves the sequential hydrogenation and oxidn. of an alkylanthraquinone precursor dissolved in a mixt. of org. solvents followed by liq.-liq. extn. to recover H2O2. The anthraquinone oxidn. process is a multistep method that requires significant energy input and generates waste, which has a neg. effect on its sustainability and prodn. costs. The transport, storage, and handling of bulk H2O2 involve hazards and escalating expenses. Thus, novel, cleaner methods for the prodn. of H2O2 are being explored. The direct synthesis of H2O2 from O2 and H2 using a variety of catalysts, and the factors influencing the formation and decompn. of H2O2 are examd.

Water is a life-giving source, yet over a billion people lack access to clean drinking water. The present techniques for water treatment such as piped, treated water rely on time and resource intensive centralized solns. In this work, we propose a decentralized device concept that can utilize sunlight to split water into hydrogen and hydrogen peroxide. The hydrogen peroxide can oxidize orgs. while the hydrogen bubbles out. In enabling this device, we require an electrocatalyst that can oxidize water while suppressing the thermodynamically favored oxygen evolution and form hydrogen peroxide. Using d. functional theory calcns., we show that the free energy of adsorbed OH* can be used to det. selectivity trends between the 2e- water oxidn. to H2O2 and the 4e- oxidn. to O2. We show that materials which bind oxygen intermediates sufficiently weakly, such as SnO2, can activate hydrogen peroxide evolution. We present a rational design principle for the selectivity in electrochem. water oxidn. and identify new material candidates that could perform H2O2 evolution selectively.

The formation of H2O2 and org. peroxides in illuminated aq. suspensions of ZnO, TiO2, and desert sand in the presence of O and org. electron donors was studied. The photocatalytic rate of formation of H2O2 on ZnO depends on the O partial pressure, on the concn. of org. electron donors, and on the concn. of H2O2. During the initial phase of irradn., the rate prodn. of H2O2 is given by d[H2O2]/dt = (Φ0 - Φ1[H2O2])(d[hν]abs)/dt), where Φ0 is the quantum yield for H2O2 formation, Φ1 is the quantum yield for H2O2 degrdn., and d[hν]abs/dt is the photon flux. The steady-state concn. of H2O2 is independent of the absorbed photon flux as predicted by the above equation; [H2O2]ss = Ψ0/Ψ1. Steady-state concns. of H2O2 of >100μM were obtained in illuminated suspensions of ZnO. In the case of ZnO, the quantum yield for H2O2 formation, Ψ0, approached 15% at 330 nm, whereas the photodegrdn. reactions were relatively inefficient. The Ψ0 for TiO2 (1% at 330 nm) was an order of magnitude less than the value for ZnO. The Ψ0 for a sample of desert sand (Death Valley, California) was 10-4. Photooxidn. of acetate and other org. electron donors on colloidal ZnO produce substantial concns. of org. peroxides, ROOH. Illumination of ZnO suspensions contg. acetate produced >40% of the measured total peroxide (H2O2 and ROOH) as ROOH.

Reactive radicals such as hydroxyl radical (OH•), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and superoxide anion (O2-) are the main power driving titanium dioxide (TiO2) photocatalytic reactions, for example, photoinduced killing of biol. cells. The effect of copper ions on the formation of H2O2 over photocatalytic TiO2 was investigated. Under an oxygen-purged soln., formation of H2O2 was increased dramatically up to 20 times by the addn. of a small amt. of copper ions. By using the Fenton reaction, the H2O2 formed can be converted into OH•, a highly reactive radical. In contrast, under nitrogen-purged soln., no H2O2 was formed even in the presence of an electron acceptor, silver ion (Ag+). These results clearly show that H2O2 was generated from the redn. site of the photoexcited TiO2 and indicate an effective way to increase the photocatalytic efficiency.

The redn. of mol. oxygen is the counter reaction of most photocatalytic reactions proceeding oxidatively on titanium dioxide particles. We have quant. analyzed the reductive prodn. of hydrogen peroxide and superoxide ion from oxygen in an aq. soln. contg. 2-propanol as the scavenger of pos. holes. The rates for the prodn. of hydrogen peroxide and superoxide ion were detd. by colorimetry using iodide and nitroblue tetrazolium, resp. In addn., the oxidn. of 2-propanol to acetone was monitored. Based on a comparison of these prodn. rates, it was concluded that the main product from oxygen is hydrogen peroxide when TiO2 powder consisting mainly of anatase-form particles is used, whereas the main product is superoxide ion when TiO2 powder consisting mainly of rutile-form particles is used. The difference in the photocatalytic activity between these powders can be attributed to the difference between the redn. paths of oxygen on these powders. It was also found that the superoxide ion generated from mol. oxygen spontaneously reacts with 2-propanol to produce acetone and hydrogen peroxide.

There is a current intense interest in water electrolysis as a means of generating or storing energy as hydrogen. The water oxidn. step typically requires high overpotentials, creating a significant energy loss in the process. Reported is water oxidn. over a MnOx electrocatalyst at low overpotentials (≈150 mV) in Bu ammonium bisulfate electrolytes (aq. 0.4 M and hydrated ionic liq. 50/50). The catalyst-electrolyte combination produces currents of the order of 1 mA cm-2 at 150 mV overpotential. A similar expt. in an inorg. electrolyte produces only negligible currents on this catalyst. The product is shown by permanganate oxidn. to be predominantly H2O2 dissolved in the electrolyte. This was confirmed by the prepn. of model solns. directly from H2O2 which were shown to behave similarly to the electrochem. prepd. solns. Ab initio calcn. of possible solvated H2O2 structures in the electrolyte suggests that the hydrogen peroxide is stabilized by a hydrogen bonded complex involving the amine. The H2O2 soln. is shown to be stable for several hours, to days, depending on the concn., but can be rapidly decompd. into oxygen by a MnO2 catalyst. The process could thus be of interest both as part of a water splitting scheme as well as a route to H2O2 for chem. use.

Rode, Baptiste; Shi, Jian; Endesh, Naima; Drinkhill, Mark J.; Webster, Peter J.; Lotteau, Sabine J.; Bailey, Marc A.; Yuldasheva, Nadira Y.; Ludlow, Melanie J.; Cubbon, Richard M.; Li, Jing; Futers, T. Simon; Morley, Lara; Gaunt, Hannah J.; Marszalek, Katarzyna; Viswambharan, Hema; Cuthbertson, Kevin; Baxter, Paul D.; Foster, Richard; Sukumar, Piruthivi; Weightman, Andrew; Calaghan, Sarah C.; Wheatcroft, Stephen B.; Kearney, Mark T.; Beech, David J.

Mammalian biol. adapts to phys. activity but the mol. mechanisms sensing the activity remain enigmatic. Recent studies have revealed how Piezo1 protein senses mech. force to enable vascular development. Here, we address Piezo1 in adult endothelium, the major control site in phys. activity. Mice without endothelial Piezo1 lack obvious phenotype but close inspection reveals a specific effect on endothelium-dependent relaxation in mesenteric resistance artery. Strikingly, the Piezo1 is required for elevated blood pressure during whole body phys. activity but not blood pressure during inactivity. Piezo1 is responsible for flow-sensitive non-inactivating non-selective cationic channels which depolarize the membrane potential. As fluid flow increases, depolarization increases to activate voltage-gated Ca2+ channels in the adjacent vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasoconstriction. Phys. performance is compromised in mice which lack endothelial Piezo1 and there is wt. loss after sustained activity. The data suggest that Piezo1 channels sense phys. activity to advantageously reset vascular control.

Electrochem. synthesis of H2O2 via 2-electron H2O oxidn. reaction (2e-WOR) is an ideal process for delocalized prodn. for H2O cleaning and other applications. Previously reported H2O oxidn. catalysts have limited activity and selectivity, imposing a bottleneck for broad adoption of this technol. The authors identify ZnO as a new stable, nontoxic, active, and selective catalyst for 2e-WOR to generate H2O2. Using d. functional theory calcns., probably the (1010) facet of ZnO is an effective catalyst for 2e-WOR and confirm the prediction exptl. The authors synthesize ZnO nanoparticles with a high fraction of (1010) facets and find that this catalyst gives an overpotential of 40 mV at 0.1 mA/cm2 and peak faradaic efficiency of 81% toward H2O2 evolution.

Platinum group metal (PGM)-free catalysts for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) have attracted increasing interest as potential candidates to replace Pt, in the view of a future widespread commercialization of polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEFC) devices, esp. for automotive applications. Among different types of PGM-free catalysts, M-N-C materials appear to be the most promising ones in terms of activity. These catalysts can be produced using a wide variety of precursors contg. C, N, and one (or more) active transition metal (mostly Fe or Co). The catalysts synthesis methods can be very different, even though they usually involve at least one pyrolysis step. In this review, five different synthesis methods are proposed, and described in detail. Several catalysts, produced approx. in the last decade, were analyzed in terms of performance in rotating disc electrode (RDE), and in H2/O2 or H2/air PEFC. The catalysts are subdivided in five different categories corresponding to the five synthesis methods described, and the RDE and PEFC performance is put in relation with the synthesis method.

There is a growing interest in pursuing Fe-free and none-Pt-based electrocatalysts for oxygen redn. to obviate the harmful Fe-involved Fenton reaction. An efficient Mn-N-C electrocatalyst toward oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) was prepd. from direct pyrolysis of a Mn(II)-based MOF (named Mn-TTPBA-4) followed by acid leaching and 2nd heat-treatment, which was solvothermally synthesized from Mn(ClO4)2 and N-rich org. linker of TTPBA-4 [N1,N1,N4,N4-tetrakis[4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenyl]benzene-1,4-diamine]. Single crystal x-ray diffraction anal. reveals that Mn-TTPBA-4 shows a 3-dimensional cationic porous architecture assembled by 1-dimensional ribbon chains extending in mutually vertical directions. The best-performing Mn-N-C catalyst exhibits a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.81 V (vs. RHE) in alk. electrolyte comparable to the ref. Pt/C, and a good long-term stability with only 10 mV neg. shift in E1/2 after 10,000 cycles.

C-based materials are considered to be active for electrochem. O redn. reaction (ORR) to H2O2 prodn. Nevertheless, less attention is paid to the study of the influence of in-plane C lattice defect on the catalytic activity and selectivity toward ORR. Graphene precursors were prepd. from oxo-functionalized graphene (oxo-G) and graphene oxide (GO) with H2O2 hydrothermal treatment, resp. Statistical Raman spectroscopy (SRS) anal. demonstrated the increased in-plane C lattice defect d. in the order of oxo-G, oxo-G/H2O2, GO, GO/H2O2. Also, N-doped graphene materials were prepd. through ammonium hydroxide hydrothermal treatment of those graphene precursors. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) results indicate that the N-doped graphene derived from oxo-G with lowest in-plane C lattice defects exhibited the highest H2O2 selectivity of >82% in 0.1M KOH. Also, a high H2O2 prodn. rate of 224.8 mmol gcatalyst-1 h-1 could be achieved at 0.2 VRHE in H-cell with faradaic efficiency of >43.6%. The authors' work provides insights for the design and synthesis of C-based electrocatalysts for H2O2 prodn.

Electro-Fenton process is an emerging treatment technol. for water and wastewater treatment. Electro-Fenton utilizes hydroxyl radicals to oxidize hazardous contaminants and is esp. useful to treat recalcitrant compds. that are not easily degraded in conventional water and wastewater treatment plants. This paper reviews the mechanism of electro-Fenton process and its kinetic modeling. The effects of electrode materials, hydrogen peroxide concn., ferrous ion concn., pH, electrolyte, oxygen sparging rate, temp., initial concn. of pollutant, feeding mode, c.d., and distance between electrodes are also reviewed. The performance of electro-Fenton is compared with other treatment technologies. Finally, existing challenges and future perspectives are discussed.

H2O2 prodn. by electroredn. of O2 is an attractive alternative to the current anthraquinone process, which is highly desirable for chem. industries and environmental remediation. However, it remains a great challenge to develop cost-effective electrocatalysts for H2O2 synthesis. Here, hierarchically porous carbon (HPC) is proposed for the electrosynthesis of H2O2 from O2 redn. It exhibited high activity for O2 redn. and good H2O2 selectivity (95.0-70.2 %, most of them >90.0% at pH 1-4 and >80.0% at pH 7). High-yield H2O2 generation was achieved on HPC with H2O2 concns. of 222.6-62.0 mmol L-1 (2.5 h) and corresponding H2O2 prodn. rates of 395.7-110.2 mmol h-1 g-1 at pH 1-7 and -0.5 V. Also, HPC was energy-efficient for H2O2 prodn. with current efficiency of 81.8-70.8%. The exceptional performance of HPC for electrosynthesis of H2O2 could be attributed to its high content of sp3-C and defects, large surface area and fast mass transfer.

In this work, the synthesis and assessment are reported of a new non-precious-metal oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) catalyst from pyrolysis of an iron-coordinated complex which manifests superior activity in both alk. and acidic media. 11,11'-bis(dipyrido[3,2-a:2',3'-c]phenazinyl) (bidppz) was selected as a ligand for the formation of a nitrogen-rich iron-coordinated coordination polymer (Fe-bidppz) which forms a self-supporting catalyst contg. high densities of nitrogen and iron doping by pyrolysis. The catalyst pyrolyzed at 800° (Fe-N/C-800) shows the highest ORR activity with onset and half-wave potentials of 923 and 809 mV in 0.1 M KOH, resp., which are comparable to those of Pt/C (half-wave potential 818 mV vs. RHE) at the same catalyst loading. Besides, the Fe-N/C-800 catalyst has an excellent ORR activity with onset and half-wave potentials only 38 and 59 mV less than those of the Pt/C catalyst in 0.1 M HClO4. The optimal Fe-N/C-800 catalyst displays much greater durability and tolerance of methanol than Pt/C. It is proposed that the Fe-N/C-800 catalyst has a considerably high d. of surface active sites because Fe-N/C-800 possesses excellent ORR activity while its sp. surface area is not so high. Electrochem. measurements show that the Fe-N/C-800 catalyst in KOH and HClO4 follows the effective four-electron-transfer pathway.

Platinum-Based Oxygen Reduction Electrocatalysts
Wu, Jianbo; Yang, Hong
Accounts of Chemical Research
(
2013
),

(

1848-1857

A review. An efficient oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) offers the potential for clean energy generation in low-temp., proton-exchange membrane fuel cells running on hydrogen fuel and air. In the past several years, researchers have developed high-performance electrocatalysts for the ORR to address the obstacles of high cost of the Pt catalyst per kW of output power and of declining catalyst activity over time. Current efforts are focused on new catalyst structures that add a secondary metal to change the d-band center and the surface at. arrangement of the catalyst, altering the chemisorption of those oxygencontaining species that have the largest impact on the ORR kinetics and improving the catalyst activity and cost effectiveness. This Account reviews recent progress in the design of Pt-based ORR electrocatalysts, including improved understanding of the reaction mechanisms and the development of synthetic methods for producing catalysts with high activity and stability. Researchers have made several types of highly active catalysts, including an extended single crystal surface of Pt and its alloy, bimetallic nanoparticles, and self-supported, low-dimensional nanostructures. We focus on the design and synthetic strategies for ORR catalysts including controlling the shape (or facet) and size of Pt and its bimetallic alloys, and controlling the surface compn. and structure of core-shell, monolayer, and hollow porous structures. The strong dependence of ORR performance on facet and size suggests that synthesizing nanocrystals with large, highly reactive {111} facets could be as important, if not more important, to increasing their activity as simply making smaller nanoparticles. A newly developed carbon-monoxide (CO)-assisted redn. method produces Pt bimetallic nanoparticles with controlled facets. This CO-based approach works well to control shapes because of the selective CO binding on different, low-indexed metal surfaces. Post-treatment under different gas environments is also important in controlling the elemental distribution, esp. the surface compn. and the core-shell and bimetallic alloy nanostructures. Besides surface compn. and facet, surface strain plays an important role in detg. the ORR activity. The surface strain depends on the crystal size, the presence of an interface-lattice mismatch or twinned boundary, and between nanocrystals and extended single crystal surfaces, all of which may be factors in metal alloys. Since the common, effective reaction pathway for the ORR is a four-electron process and the surface binding of oxygen-contg. species is typically the limiting step, d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. is useful for predicting the ORR performance over bimetallic catalysts. Finally, we have noticed there are variations among the published values for activity and durability of ORR catalysts in recent papers. The differences are often due to the data quality and protocols used for carrying out the anal. using a rotating disk electrode (RDE). Thus, we briefly discuss some practices used in such half-cell measurements, such as sample prepn. and measurement, data reliability (in both kinetic c.d. and durability measurement) and iR correction that could lead to more consistency in measured values and in evaluating catalyst performances.

Chen, Zhongwei; Higgins, Drew; Yu, Aiping; Zhang, Lei; Zhang, Jiujun

A review. With the approaching commercialization of PEM fuel cell technol., developing active, inexpensive non-precious metal ORR catalyst materials to replace currently used Pt-based catalysts is a necessary and essential requirement in order to reduce the overall system cost. This review paper highlights the progress made over the past 40 years with a detailed discussion of recent works in the area of non-precious metal electrocatalysts for oxygen redn. reaction, a necessary reaction at the PEM fuel cell cathode. Several important kinds of unsupported or carbon supported non-precious metal electrocatalysts for ORR are reviewed, including non-pyrolyzed and pyrolyzed transition metal nitrogen-contg. complexes, conductive polymer-based catalysts, transition metal chalcogenides, metal oxides/carbides/nitrides/oxynitrides/carbonitrides, and enzymic compds. Among these candidates, pyrolyzed transition metal nitrogen-contg. complexes supported on carbon materials (M-Nx/C) are considered the most promising ORR catalysts because they have demonstrated some ORR activity and stability close to that of com. available Pt/C catalysts. Although great progress has been achieved in this area of research and development, there are still some challenges in both their ORR activity and stability. Regarding the ORR activity, the actual volumetric activity of the most active non-precious metal catalyst is still well below the DOE 2015 target. Regarding the ORR stability, stability tests are generally run at low current densities or low power levels, and the lifetime is far shorter than targets set by DOE. Therefore, improving both the ORR activity and stability are the major short and long term focuses of non-precious metal catalyst research and development. Based on the results achieved in this area, several future research directions are also proposed and discussed in this paper.

Platinum group metal-free (PGM-free) metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts have emerged as a promising alternative to their costly platinum (Pt)-based counterparts in polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs) but still face some major challenges, including (i) the identification of the most relevant catalytic site for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and (ii) demonstration of competitive PEFC performance under automotive-application conditions in the hydrogen (H2)-air fuel cell. Herein, we demonstrate H2-air performance gains achieved with an iron-nitrogen-carbon catalyst synthesized with two nitrogen precursors that developed hierarchical porosity. Current densities recorded in the kinetic region of cathode operation, at fuel cell voltages greater than ∼0.75 V, were the same as those obtained with a Pt cathode at a loading of 0.1 mg of Pt per cm squared. The proposed catalytic active site, carbon-embedded nitrogen-coordinated iron (FeN4), was directly visualized with aberration-cor. scanning transmission electron microscopy, and the contributions of these active sites assocd. with specific lattice-level carbon structures were explored computationally.

A review. The development of non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) that are practical for use at the cathode of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) would provide immense economic advantages, perpetuating the looming widespread commercialization of these devices. NPMC materials with excellent activity towards the oxygen redn., coupled with PEMFC performance approaching that of state-of-the-art platinum catalysts brings this technol. one step closer to practical application. Currently, the stability of these materials is still limited, and developing NPMC with excellent activity, performance and operational stability is the holy grail of PEMFC catalyst research. Fundamental knowledge available, along with recent progress made in this field of research will be the subject of this review paper.

The electrochem. redn. of O to H2O2 is a particularly promising means of achieving this aim. However, it would require active, selective and stable materials to catalyze the reaction. A review. Despite the dedicated search for novel catalysts for fuel cell applications, the intrinsic oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) activity of materials has not improved significantly over the past decade. Here, we review the role of theory in understanding the ORR mechanism and highlight the descriptor-based approaches that have been used to identify catalysts with increased activity. Specifically, by showing that the performance of the commonly studied materials (e.g., metals, alloys, carbons, etc.) is limited by unfavorable scaling relationships (for binding energies of reaction intermediates), we present a no. of alternative strategies that may lead to the design and discovery of more promising materials for ORR.

Nitrogen-doped carbon materials featuring atomically dispersed metal cations (M-N-C) are an emerging family of materials with potential applications for electrocatalysis. The electrocatalytic activity of M-N-C materials toward four-electron oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) to H2O is a mainstream line of research for replacing platinum-group-metal-based catalysts at the cathode of fuel cells. However, fundamental and practical aspects of their electrocatalytic activity toward two-electron ORR to H2O2, a future green "dream" process for chem. industry, remain poorly understood. Here we combined computational and exptl. efforts to uncover the trends in electrochem. H2O2 prodn. over a series of M-N-C materials (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) exclusively comprising atomically dispersed M-Nx sites from mol. first-principles to bench-scale electrolyzers operating at industrial c.d. We investigated the effect of the nature of a 3d metal within a series of M-N-C catalysts on the electrocatalytic activity/selectivity for ORR (H2O2 and H2O products) and H2O2 redn. reaction (H2O2RR). Co-N-C catalyst was uncovered with outstanding H2O2 productivity considering its high ORR activity, highest H2O2 selectivity, and lowest H2O2RR activity. The activity-selectivity trend over M-N-C materials was further analyzed by d. functional theory, providing mol.-scale understandings of exptl. volcano trends for four- and two-electron ORR. The predicted binding energy of HO* intermediate over Co-N-C catalyst is located near the top of the volcano accounting for favorable two-electron ORR. The industrial H2O2 productivity over Co-N-C catalyst was demonstrated in a microflow cell, exhibiting an unprecedented prodn. rate of more than 4 mol peroxide gcatalyst-1 h-1 at a c.d. of 50 mA cm-2.
