A review. This 2007 Chem. Nobel prize update covers scientific advances of the past decade in our understanding of electrocatalytic processes on surfaces of nanoscale shape-controlled polyhedral solids. It is argued that the field of chem. reaction processes on solid surfaces has recently been paying increasing attention to the fundamental understanding of electrified solid-liq. interfaces and toward the operando study of the minute fraction of catalytically active, structurally dynamic non-equil. Taylor-type surface sites. Meanwhile, despite mounting evidence of acting as structural proxies in some cases, the concept of catalytic structure sensitivity of well-defined nanoscale solid surfaces continues to be a key organizing principle for the science of shape-controlled nanocrystals and, hence, constitutes a central recurring theme in this review. After addressing key aspects and recent progress in the wet-chem. synthesis of shaped nanocatalysts, three areas of electrocatalytic processes on solid shape-controlled nanocrystals of current scientific priority are discussed in more detail: the oxygen electroredn. on shape-controlled Pt-Ni polyhedra with its technol. relevance for low temp. fuel cells, the CO2 electroredn. to hydrocarbons on Cu polyhedra and the puzzling interplay between chem. and structural effects, and the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction from water on shaped transition metal oxides.

Shape-controlled octahedral Pt-Ni alloy nanoparticles exhibit remarkably high activities for the electroredn. of O2 (ORR), which makes them fuel cell cathode catalysts with exceptional potential. To unfold their full and optimized catalytic activity and stability, however, the nano-octahedra require post-synthesis thermal treatments, which alter the surface at. structure and compn. of the crystal facets. Here, the authors address and strive to elucidate the underlying surface chem. processes using a combination of ex situ anal. techniques with in situ TEM, in situ XRD, and in situ electrochem. Fourier transformed IR (FTIR) expts. The authors present a robust fundamental correlation between annealing temp. and catalytic activity, where a ∼ 25x higher ORR activity than com. Pt/C (2.7 A mgPt-1 at 0.9 VRHE) was reproducibly obsd. at annealing at 300°. The electrochem. stability, however, peaked without any and at the most severe heat treatments at 500°. Aberration-cor. scanning TEM (STEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDX) in combination with in situ electrochem. CO stripping/FTIR data revealed subtle, but important differences in the formation and chem. nature of Pt rich and Ni rich surface domains in the octahedral (111) facets. Estg. trends in surface chemisorption energies from in situ electrochem. CO / FTIR studies suggested that balanced annealing generates an optimal degree of Pt surface enrichment, while the others exhibited mostly Ni rich facets. The insights from the authors' study are quite generally valid and aid in developing suitable post synthesis thermal treatments for other alloy nanocatalysts as well.

Bacterial cellulose/polyaniline (BC/PANi) blends present a great potential for several applications. The current study evaluates the impact of using different BC matrixes (drained, freeze-dried and regenerated) and different synthesis conditions (in situ and ex situ) to improve the inherent properties of BC, which were monitored through FTIR-ATR, EDX, XRD, SEM, AFM, swelling, contact angle measurement and IGC. The employment of in situ polymn. onto drained BC presented the most conductive membrane (1.4×10-1S/cm). The crystallinity, swelling capacity, surface energy and acid/base behavior of the BC membranes is substantially modified upon PANi incorporation, being dependent on the BC matrix used, being the freeze-dried BC blends the ones with highest crystallinity (up to 54%), swelling capacity (up to 414%) and surface energy (up to 75.0 J/m2). Hence, this work evidenced that the final properties of the BC/PANi blends are greatly influenced by both the BC matrixes and synthesis methods employed.

We adopted 1-step pyrolysis method to synthesize the Co nanoparticle-embedded, Ni and N co-doped carbon composites (Ni/Co/NC) by using ZIF-67 as precursor. We systematic analyzed the influence of Ni on its phys. and chem. properties. All samples were characterized by XRD, SEM, EDS, and TEM. The ORR activities were evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and rotating disk electrode (RDE) technol. Ni was successfully dispersed in Co/NC. The ORR onset potential of Co/NC is 0.847 V. When Co/NC was doped with 25%, 50%, and 75% Ni, its ORR onset potential is 0.854, 0.876, and 0.865 V, resp. 0.50Ni/Co/NC has dodecahedral morphol. and hollow structure. The Tafel slope value of Co/NC, 0.25Ni/Co/NC, 0.50Ni/Co/NC, and 0.75Ni/Co/NC is 0.97, 0.91, 0.82, and 0.89 mV/de, resp. 0.50Ni/Co/NC exhibits the most efficient properties for ORR.

C-based materials are considered to be active for electrochem. O redn. reaction (ORR) to H2O2 prodn. Nevertheless, less attention is paid to the study of the influence of in-plane C lattice defect on the catalytic activity and selectivity toward ORR. Graphene precursors were prepd. from oxo-functionalized graphene (oxo-G) and graphene oxide (GO) with H2O2 hydrothermal treatment, resp. Statistical Raman spectroscopy (SRS) anal. demonstrated the increased in-plane C lattice defect d. in the order of oxo-G, oxo-G/H2O2, GO, GO/H2O2. Also, N-doped graphene materials were prepd. through ammonium hydroxide hydrothermal treatment of those graphene precursors. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) results indicate that the N-doped graphene derived from oxo-G with lowest in-plane C lattice defects exhibited the highest H2O2 selectivity of >82% in 0.1M KOH. Also, a high H2O2 prodn. rate of 224.8 mmol gcatalyst-1 h-1 could be achieved at 0.2 VRHE in H-cell with faradaic efficiency of >43.6%. The authors' work provides insights for the design and synthesis of C-based electrocatalysts for H2O2 prodn.

A review. This 2007 Chem. Nobel prize update covers scientific advances of the past decade in our understanding of electrocatalytic processes on surfaces of nanoscale shape-controlled polyhedral solids. It is argued that the field of chem. reaction processes on solid surfaces has recently been paying increasing attention to the fundamental understanding of electrified solid-liq. interfaces and toward the operando study of the minute fraction of catalytically active, structurally dynamic non-equil. Taylor-type surface sites. Meanwhile, despite mounting evidence of acting as structural proxies in some cases, the concept of catalytic structure sensitivity of well-defined nanoscale solid surfaces continues to be a key organizing principle for the science of shape-controlled nanocrystals and, hence, constitutes a central recurring theme in this review. After addressing key aspects and recent progress in the wet-chem. synthesis of shaped nanocatalysts, three areas of electrocatalytic processes on solid shape-controlled nanocrystals of current scientific priority are discussed in more detail: the oxygen electroredn. on shape-controlled Pt-Ni polyhedra with its technol. relevance for low temp. fuel cells, the CO2 electroredn. to hydrocarbons on Cu polyhedra and the puzzling interplay between chem. and structural effects, and the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction from water on shaped transition metal oxides.

A review. Electrochem. synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) provides a clean and safe technol. for large-scale H2O2 prodn. The core of this project is the development of highly active and highly selective catalysts. Recent studies demonstrate that carbonaceous materials are favorable catalysts because of their low-cost and tunable surface structures. This brief review first summarizes the strategies of carbonaceous material engineering for selective two-electron O2 redn. reaction and discusses potential mechanisms. In addn., several device designs using carbonaceous materials as catalysts for H2O2 prodn. are introduced. Finally, research directions are proposed for practical application and performance improvement.

Platinum group metal (PGM)-free catalysts that are also iron free are highly desirable for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, as they avoid possible Fenton reactions. Here we report an efficient ORR catalyst that consists of atomically dispersed nitrogen-coordinated single Mn sites on partially graphitic carbon (Mn-N-C). Evidence for the embedding of the atomically dispersed MnN4 moieties within the carbon surface-exposed basal planes was established by X-ray absorption spectroscopy and their dispersion was confirmed by aberration-cor. electron microscopy with at. resoln. The Mn-N-C catalyst exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.80 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode, approaching that of Fe-N-C catalysts, along with significantly enhanced stability in acidic media. The encouraging performance of the Mn-N-C catalyst as a PGM-free cathode was demonstrated in fuel cell tests. First-principles calcns. further support the MnN4 sites as the origin of the ORR activity via a 4e- pathway in acidic media.

A review. Pyrolyzed metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) materials have become a mainstream research as inexpensive and sustainable catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in both acid and alk. media for low and intermediate temp. fuel cells. Tremendous advancements in the initial activity and power performance of M-N-C catalysts and cathodes have been achieved, as driven by their possible application in e.g. automotive fuel cell stacks. Based on a selected no. of recent studies, this review critically discusses the advancements, but also highlights the remaining scientific questions and tech. issues important in this field. The nature of the active site(s) as well as their intrinsic activity toward ORR have been clarified in particular through the prepn. of model catalysts comprising only MNxCy moieties. Recently developed methods hold promise to reliably enumerate the no. of electrochem. accessible active sites in such materials, which would allow deconvoluting the activity into site d. and turnover frequency.

Co tetramethoxyphenylporphyrin (CoTMPP) adsorbed on a high area C support (Vulcan XC72-R) and heat-treated at 900° under inert atm. was studied as electrocatalyst for the redn. of O2 to H2O2 in acid medium. Expts. performed on rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) and gas diffusion electrode (GDE) show that the catalyst performance depends on the Co loading, going through a max. at 0.2% Co. For higher Co loadings, a growing part of oxygen is reduced into H2O, decreasing therefore the selectivity of the catalyst. These results are interpreted in terms of a further redn. of H2O2 on Co-based catalytic sites before leaving the catalytic layer. For a GDE polarized at -150 mV vs. SCE and loaded with 0.9 μg cm-2 of 0.2% Co-based catalyst, a H2O2 prodn. rate of 300 μmol h-1 cm-2 was obtained which is 5 times higher than the H2O2 prodn. rate measured with Vulcan. Under these conditions, the selectivity of the Co-based catalyst for H2O2 prodn. is 92%. The good agreement obsd. between RRDE and GDE results confirms the relevance of using RRDE expt. for screening these nonprecious metal catalysts for further GDE applications.

C supports, including vapor grown C fiber (VGCF), activated C (a.c.), C black XC-72 (XC72), and C black Black-Pearl-2000/3500 (BP2000/3500), strongly affected the electrocatalysis of the Co-TPP/C. The Co-TPP/VGCF heat-treated at 1023 K, abbreviated as Co-TPP/VGCF(1073), showed a good electrocatalytic activity for H2O2 formation (1.0 mol dm-3 with 40% current efficiency (CE)); however, other C supports were unfavorable. Their electrocatalysis were studied by rotating ring-disk electrode voltammetry and kinetic studies of the decompn. of H2O2 and the electroredn. of H2O2 to H2O. The electrocatalytic activities for the successive redn. of H2O2 to H2O detd. the final H2O2 concns. and CEs. An active site of heat-treated Co-TPP/VGCF was characterized by XPS, and x-ray absorption near-edge fine structure spectroscopy. Partial pyrolysis of Co-TPP on the C surface was essential to generate the active site for the H2O2 formation. A model of the Co active site, CoN2-C, is proposed.

The electrochem. oxygen redn. reaction in acidic media offers an attractive route for direct hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) generation and on-site applications. Unfortunately there is still a lack of cost-effective electrocatalysts with high catalytic performance. Here, we theor. designed and exptl. demonstrated that a cobalt single-atom catalyst (Co SAC) anchored in nitrogen-doped graphene, with optimized adsorption energy of the *OOH intermediate, exhibited a high H2O2 prodn. rate, which even slightly outperformed the state-of-the-art noble-metal-based electrocatalysts. The kinetic current of H2O2 prodn. over Co SAC could reach 1 mA/cm2disk at 0.6 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode in 0.1 M HClO4 with H2O2 faraday efficiency > 90%, and these performance measures could be sustained for 10 h without decay. Further kinetic anal. and operando X-ray absorption study combined with d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. demonstrated that the nitrogen-coordinated single Co atom was the active site and the reaction was rate-limited by the first electron transfer step.

The prohibitive cost of platinum for catalyzing the cathodic oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) has hampered the widespread use of polymer electrolyte fuel cells. We describe a family of non-precious metal catalysts that approach the performance of platinum-based systems at a cost sustainable for high-power fuel cell applications, possibly including automotive power. The approach uses polyaniline as a precursor to a carbon-nitrogen template for high-temp. synthesis of catalysts incorporating iron and cobalt. The most active materials in the group catalyze the ORR at potentials within ~60 mV of that delivered by state-of-the-art carbon-supported platinum, combining their high activity with remarkable performance stability for non-precious metal catalysts (700 h at a fuel cell voltage of 0.4 V) as well as excellent four-electron selectivity (hydrogen peroxide yield <1.0%).

The scaling up of electrocatalytic CO2 redn. for practical applications is still hindered by a few challenges: low selectivity, small c.d. to maintain a reasonable selectivity, and the cost of the catalytic materials. Here we report a facile synthesis of earth-abundant Ni single-atom catalysts on com. carbon black, which were further employed in a gas-phase electrocatalytic reactor under ambient conditions. As a result, those single-at. sites exhibit an extraordinary performance in reducing CO2 to CO, yielding a c.d. above 100 mA cm-2, with nearly 100% selectivity for CO and around 1% toward the hydrogen evolution side reaction. By further scaling up the electrode into a 10 × 10-cm2 modular cell, the overall current in one unit cell can easily ramp up to more than 8 A while maintaining an exclusive CO evolution with a generation rate of 3.34 L hr-1 per unit cell.

The growth dynamics of bamboo-like multiwalled carbon nanotubes (BCNTs) via catalytic decompn. of C2H2 on Ni catalyst at 650 °C was obsd. in real time using an in situ ultrahigh vacuum transmission electron microscope. During BCNT growth, the shape of the catalyst particle changes constantly but remains metallic and cryst. Graphene sheets (bamboo knots) within the nanotube preferentially nucleate on the multistep Ni-graphite edges at the point where the graphene joins the catalyst particle, where it is stabilized by both the graphene walls and the Ni catalyst surface. The growth of a complete inner graphene layer prior to contraction of the Ni catalyst particle due to restoring cohesive forces will result in a complete BCNT knot whereas partial growth of the inner wall will lead to an incomplete BCNT knot.

Electrode potential-pH (Pourbaix) diagrams provide a phase map of the most stable compds. of a metal, its corrosion products, and assocd. ions in soln. The utility of these phase diagrams is that they enable the assessment of electrochem. stabilities, for example, of Ni metal and its derived oxides, hydroxides, and oxyhydroxides, against corrosion in aq. environments. Remarkably, the Ni Pourbaix diagrams reported over the last 50 years are largely inconsistent with various electrochem. observations, which may be attributed to inaccurate exptl. free energies of formation (ΔfG) for the complex Ni-based compds. used in producing the available diagrams. State-of-the-art d.-functional theory (DFT) can be used to obtain accurate ΔfG values, which lead to Ni Pourbaix diagrams that are more consistent with direct electrochem. expts.: Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy were used to characterize the electrochem. stabilities of NiO and Ni(OH)2 formed on Ni, demonstrating the reliability in correction-free 1st-principles based Pourbaix diagrams. The authors' results show the importance in applying modern d. functionals in combination with exptl. advances in aq. environment compd. identification for assessing electrochem. phase stability of materials, which will be useful for the design, synthesis, and selection of corrosion-resistant metals, photoabsorbers, and photocatalytic materials.

Electrochem. H2O2 (H2O2) prodn. by two-electron O redn. is a promising alternative process to the established industrial anthraquinone process. Current challenges relate to finding cost-effective electrocatalysts with high electrocatalytic activity, stability, and product selectivity. Here, the authors explore the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity toward H2O2 prodn. of a no. of distinct N-doped mesoporous C catalysts and report a previously unachieved H2O2 selectivity of ∼95-98% in acidic soln. To explain the authors' observations, the authors correlate their structural, compositional, and other physicochem. properties with their electrocatalytic performance and uncover a close correlation between the H2O2 product yield and the surface area and interfacial zeta potential. N doping was found to sharply boost H2O2 activity and selectivity. Chronoamperometric H2O2 electrolysis confirms the exceptionally high H2O2 prodn. rate and large H2O2 faradaic selectivity for the optimal N-doped CMK-3 sample in acidic, neutral, and alk. solns. In alk. soln., the catalytic H2O2 yield increases further, where the prodn. rate of the HO2- anion reaches a value ≤561.7 mmol gcatalyst-1 h-1 with H2O2 faradaic selectivity >70%. The authors' work provides a guide for the design, synthesis, and mechanistic study of advanced C-based electrocatalysts for H2O2 prodn.

By using first-principles calcns., we investigate the structural stability of nitrogen-doped (N-doped) graphene with graphitic-N, pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N, and the transition metal (TM) atoms embedded into N-doped graphene. The structures and energetics of TM atoms from Sc to Ni embedded into N-doped graphene are studied. The TM atoms at N4V 2 forming a 4N-centered structure shows the strongest binding and the binding energies are more than 7 eV. Finally, we investigate the catalytic performance of N-doped graphene with and without TM embedding for O2 dissocn., which is a fundamental reaction in fuel cells. Compared to the pyridinic-N, the graphitic-N is more favorable to dissoc. O2 mols. with a relatively low reaction barrier of 1.15 eV. However, the catalytic performance on pyridinic-N doped structure can be greatly improved by embedding TM atoms, and the energy barrier can be reduced to 0.61 eV with V atom embedded. Our results provide the stable structure of N-doped graphene and its potential applications in the oxygen redn. reactions. (c) 2015 American Institute of Physics.

Co-based catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in an acid medium were prepd. from Co acetate (Co(OAc)2) adsorbed on 9 different carbons (previously enriched in surface nitrogen or not). The catalysts were obtained by heat-treating these materials at 900° in a reducing environment rich in NH3. The emphasis was mainly placed on the electrochem. prodn. of H2O2 as measured by the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) technique. All Co-based catalysts are active for ORR. The activity and specificity of the catalysts for peroxide prodn. depend essentially on 3 factors: (i) the potential applied to the disk, (ii) the type of C support; and (iii) the concn. of the Co precursor. At identical Co loadings (2000 ppm), the percentage of peroxide produced at the disk (%H2O2) reaches a max. in the 0.3-0.1 V vs. SCE potential range and decreases for more neg. potentials. When the potential is set at a const. value (100 mV vs. SCE for instance), a strong effect of the C support on %H2O2 and on the ring current IR is noticed, with lower values of %H2O2 and IR corresponding to higher nitrogen content at the surface of the catalysts, while higher values of disk current ID are obtained under the same conditions. A figure of merit for the electroredn. of oxygen to H2O2 was obtained for each catalyst by multiplying ID (representing their activity for ORR) by %H2O2 (representing their specificity for H2O2 prodn.). According to this figure of merit, the best catalysts for peroxide prodn. are made with Ketjenblack, Black Pearls, Vulcan, and Norit C supports. For Co loadings >2000 ppm, increasing the loading by >1 order of magnitude (from 2000 to 50,000 ppm) has practically no effect on %H2O2 and IR, while ID decreases.

Objective evaluation of the activity of electrocatalysts for water oxidn. is of fundamental importance for the development of promising energy conversion technologies including integrated solar water-splitting devices, water electrolyzers, and Li-air batteries. However, current methods employed to evaluate oxygen-evolving catalysts are not standardized, making it difficult to compare the activity and stability of these materials. We report a protocol for evaluating the activity, stability, and Faradaic efficiency of electrodeposited oxygen-evolving electrocatalysts. In particular, we focus on methods for detg. electrochem. active surface area and measuring electrocatalytic activity and stability under conditions relevant to an integrated solar water-splitting device. Our primary figure of merit is the overpotential required to achieve a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 per geometric area, approx. the c.d. expected for a 10% efficient solar-to-fuels conversion device. Utilizing the aforementioned surface area measurements, one can det. electrocatalyst turnover frequencies. The reported protocol was used to examine the oxygen-evolution activity of the following systems in acidic and alk. solns.: CoOx, CoPi, CoFeOx, NiOx, NiCeOx, NiCoOx, NiCuOx, NiFeOx, and NiLaOx. The oxygen-evolving activity of an electrodeposited IrOx catalyst was also investigated for comparison. Two general observations are made from comparing the catalytic performance of the OER catalysts investigated: (1) in alk. soln., every non-noble metal system achieved 10 mA cm-2 current densities at similar operating overpotentials between 0.35 and 0.43 V, and (2) every system but IrOx was unstable under oxidative conditions in acidic solns.

Twelve well-characterized activated carbons with av. micropore widths between 0.7 and 2 nm, total surface areas of 378-1270 m2 g-1 and specific capacitances C up to 320 F g-1 were investigated, using H2SO4 2 M as electrolyte. Some of the carbons were also oxidized with (NH4)2S2O8, which leads to specific oxygen contents between 0.4-7.1 μmol m-2 of C surface area. It appears that Co, the limiting capacitance at a c.d. of 1 mA cm-2 of electrode surface, does not depend significantly on the O content. An empirical equation is proposed to describe the decrease of C with increasing c.d. d (1-70 mA cm-2 of electrode surface), as a function of the O content. As suggested by different authors, Co can be expressed as a sum of contributions from the external surface area Se and the surface of the micropores Smi. A closer investigation shows that Co/Smi increases with the pore size and reaches values as high as 0.250-0.270 F m-2 for supermicropores. It is suggested that the vol. W*0 of the electrolyte found between the surface layers in pores wider than 0.7-0.8 nm contributes to Co. However, this property is limited to microporosity, like the enthalpy of immersion of the carbons into benzene. The latter is also correlated to Co, which provides a useful means to identify potential supercapacitors.

A review. The electrochem. O redn. reaction (ORR) via the two-electron pathway provides a promising approach for the direct synthesis of H2O2 (H2O2) and its on-site uses. The effective electrocatalyst is one of the key factors detg. the future applications of this technol. In recent years, various catalysts, such as pristine C materials, modified C materials (oxidized or heteroatom doped such as N, F, or S doped), Au, or Hg alloyed Pd or Pt nanoparticles, as well as transition metal single atom catalysts (SACs) are reported to effectively catalyze the H2O2 prodn. via the two-electron ORR process. Among these candidates, SACs with 100% atom use and well-defined active centers attracted extra attention due to their high catalytic performance for H2O2 synthesis. In this review, the thermodn., O mol. activation, and theor. screening and prediction of SACs for electrochem. H2O2 synthesis are discussed. The catalytic performance, reaction kinetics and mechanism of SACs together with electrochem. devices for H2O2 synthesis via the two-electron ORR are summarized. It is hoped that this contribution can offer a comprehensive ref. for the progress of SACs in H2O2 electrochem. prodn. process.

We have investigated the impact of electrocatalyst loading on rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) expts. for the oxygen redn. reaction on Fe-N-C catalysts (ORR) in acid medium. In particular, the fraction of H2O2 produced as a function of catalyst loading was studied. A dramatic increase in H2O2 release was obsd. as the catalyst loading was decreased. For the same non-noble metal catalyst (NNMC), the fraction of produced H2O2 varied between less than 5% and greater than 95%, depending on the catalyst loading. These observations suggest that oxygen redn. occurs stepwise, via H2O2, and if the catalyst is sparsely loaded, the produced H2O2 cannot be efficiently reduced to H2O before it escapes. These studies have important implications for fundamental studies of ORR on NNMCs.

A highly active non-platinum group metal (non-PGM) catalyst derived from iron and 4-aminoantipyrine precursors was synthesized using a sacrificial support method (SSM) to obtain a highly porous, open framed structure. The ratio of iron to 4-aminoantipyrine had been previously optimized to catalyze the redn. of oxygen in both acid and alk. media. In this study, the mechanism of the redn. of oxygen in both media was investigated, and it was found to follow the 2 × 2 pathway. On its face, electrochem. anal. seems to suggest that the direct 4 electron transfer pathway is favored due to the low peroxide yield, but a closer examn. reveals that the 2 × 2 pathway is followed, where the fast step is the partial redn. to peroxide, and the ensuing redn. step to water is also fairly rapid.

The effect of catalyst loading levels on the O redn. reaction (ORR) selectivity for H2O formation on both N-contg. nanostructured C (CNx) and com. Pt/Vulcan C (VC) catalysts was examd. using the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) method. Catalyst loadings from 142 to 1420 μg/cm2 were studied. Catalyst loading played a significant role in detg. the selectivity for H2O formation, with lower loading levels showing a much higher selectivity for H2O2. The phenomenon was probed by examg. the exptl. collection efficiencies of the RRDE for each loading level and the catalyst thickness with SEM. The difference between exptl. and theor. collection efficiencies did not contribute significantly to the change in selectivity, although catalyst thickness did. Apparently a multistep mechanism where H2O2 is an intermediate can account for this behavior. More of this H2O2 intermediate can be detected when the reaction path length (catalyst thickness) is reduced. H2O2 electroredn. expts. showed the CNx materials to have the ability to catalyze further redn. of H2O2 to H2O, supporting the possibility of a two-step mechanism.

Metal, nitrogen-doped carbon materials have attracted interest as heterogenous catalysts that contain MNx active sites that are analogus to mol. catalysts. Of particular interest is Ni,N-doped carbon, a catalyst that is active for the electrochem. redn. of CO2 to CO. Crit. to the understanding of these materials is proof of single at. sites and characterization of the environment surrounding the metal atom; however, directly probing this coordination remains challenging. This challenge is addressed by combining scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), single atom electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS). Through STEM imaging, at. dispersion of Ni in the carbon framework is confirmed and image analyses are utilized to give semiquant. ests. of neighbor distance distributions and site densities of Ni atoms. Atomic resoln. EELS demonstrates that N and Ni are colocated at the single Ni atom sites suggesting Ni-N coordination. ToF-SIMS reveals a distribution of NiNxCy- fragments that reflect the Ni-N bonding environments within Ni,N-doped carbon. The fragmentation from Ni,N-doped carbon is similar to Ni phthalocyanine, suggesting the existence of heterogenized, mol.-like NiN4 active sites which motivates future studies that leverage insight from mol. catalysis design to develop next-generation heterogeneous catalysts.

Li, Xiaogang; Bi, Wentuan; Chen, Minglong; Sun, Yuexiang; Ju, Huanxin; Yan, Wensheng; Zhu, Junfa; Wu, Xiaojun; Chu, Wangsheng; Wu, Changzheng; Xie, Yi

Electrochem. redn. of CO2 (CO2) to value-added C products is a promising approach to reduce CO2 levels and mitigate the energy crisis. However, poor product selectivity is still a major obstacle to the development of CO2 redn. Here the authors demonstrate exclusive Ni-N4 sites through a topo-chem. transformation strategy, bringing unprecedentedly high activity and selectivity for CO2 redn. Topo-chem. transformation by C layer coating successfully ensures preservation of the Ni-N4 structure to a max. extent and avoids the agglomeration of Ni atoms to particles, providing abundant active sites for the catalytic reaction. The Ni-N4 structure exhibits excellent activity for electrochem. redn. of CO2 with particularly high selectivity, achieving high faradaic efficiency over 90% for CO in the potential range from -0.5 to -0.9 V and gives a max. faradaic efficiency of 99% at -0.81 V with a c.d. of 28.6 mA cm-2. The authors anticipate exclusive catalytic sites will shed new light on the design of high-efficiency electrocatalysts for CO2 redn.

Atomic-level active sites of efficient imidazolate framework-derived nickel catalysts for CO2 reduction
Pan, Fuping; Zhang, Hanguang; Liu, Zhenyu; Cullen, David; Liu, Kexi; More, Karren; Wu, Gang; Wang, Guofeng; Li, Ying
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability

Royal Society of Chemistry

Nickel and nitrogen co-doped carbon (Ni-N-C) has emerged as a promising catalyst for the CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR); however, the chem. nature of its active sites has remained elusive. Herein, the exploration is reported of the reactivity and active sites of Ni-N-C for the CO2RR. Single atom Ni coordinated with N confined in a carbon matrix was prepd. through thermal activation of chem. Ni-doped zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and directly visualized by aberration-cor. scanning transmission electron microscopy. Electrochem. results show the enhanced intrinsic reactivity and selectivity of Ni-N sites for the redn. of CO2 to CO, delivering a max. CO faradaic efficiency of 96% at a low overpotential of 570 mV. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. predict that the edge-located Ni-N2+2 sites with dangling bond-contg. carbon atoms are the active sites facilitating the dissocn. of the C-O bond of the *COOH intermediate, while bulk-hosted Ni-N4 is kinetically inactive. Furthermore, the high capability of edge-located Ni-N4 being able to thermodynamically suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution is also explained. The proposal of edge-hosed Ni-N2+2 sites provides new insight into designing high-efficiency Ni-N-C for CO2 redn.

Electrodeposited thin films and nanoparticles of Ni3S2 are highly active, poison- and corrosion-resistant catalysts for oxygen redn. to water at neutral pH. In pH 7 phosphate buffer, Ni3S2 displays catalytic onset at 0.8 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode, a Tafel slope of 109 mV/decade, and high faradaic efficiency for four-electron redn. of O2 to water. Under these conditions, the activity and stability of Ni3S2 exceeds that of polycryst. platinum and manganese, nickel, and cobalt oxides, illustrating the catalytic potential of pairing labile first-row transition metal active sites with a more covalent sulfide host lattice.

M-N-C electrocatalysts (where M is Fe or Co) have been investigated for mitigating the dependence on noble metals when catalyzing the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) for fuel cell technologies in acidic or alk. conditions. Rotating disk and rotating ring-disk electrode measurements for Fe-N-C and Co-N-C catalysts demonstrate promising performances and stability for the ORR, while the activity of main suspected active sites (M-NxCy and
[email protected]
) has been discussed on the basis of the known phys.-chem. properties of the catalysts in acid and alk. media. Thereupon, it is obsd. that atomically dispersed Fe-NxCy sites reach the highest ORR activity in acid media when amplified by an adequate energy binding between the metallic center and the oxygenated reaction intermediates. In contrast,
[email protected]
core-shell sites reach a max. ORR mass activity in alk. media through a synergistic effect involving catalyst particles with metallic iron in the core and nitrogen-doped carbon in the shell.

A review of processes of prodn. of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is widely used in almost all industrial areas, particularly in the chem. industry and environmental protection. The only degrdn. product of its use is water, and thus it has played a large role in environmentally friendly methods in the chem. industry. Hydrogen peroxide is produced on an industrial scale by the anthraquinone oxidn. process. However, this process can hardly be considered a green method. It involves the sequential hydrogenation and oxidn. of an alkylanthraquinone precursor dissolved in a mixt. of org. solvents followed by liq.-liq. extn. to recover H2O2. The anthraquinone oxidn. process is a multistep method that requires significant energy input and generates waste, which has a neg. effect on its sustainability and prodn. costs. The transport, storage, and handling of bulk H2O2 involve hazards and escalating expenses. Thus, novel, cleaner methods for the prodn. of H2O2 are being explored. The direct synthesis of H2O2 from O2 and H2 using a variety of catalysts, and the factors influencing the formation and decompn. of H2O2 are examd.

Defective Carbon-Based Materials for the Electrochemical Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide
Chen, Shucheng; Chen, Zhihua; Siahrostami, Samira; Kim, Taeho Roy; Nordlund, Dennis; Sokaras, Dimosthenis; Nowak, Stanislaw; To, John W. F.; Higgins, Drew; Sinclair, Robert; Noerskov, Jens K.; Jaramillo, Thomas F.; Bao, Zhenan

Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), an important industrial chem., is currently produced through an energy-intensive anthraquinone process that is limited to large-scale facilities. Small-scale decentralized electrochem. prodn. of H2O2 via a two-electron oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) offers unique opportunities for sanitization applications and the purifn. of drinking water. The development of inexpensive, efficient, and selective catalysts for this reaction remains a challenge. Herein, we examine two different porous carbon-based electrocatalysts and show that they exhibit high selectivity for H2O2 under alk. conditions. By rationally varying synthetic methods, we explore the effect of pore size on electrocatalytic performance. Furthermore, by means of d. functional calcns., we point out the crit. role of carbon defects. Our theory results show that the majority of defects in graphene are naturally selective for the two-electron redn. of O2 to H2O2, and we identify the types of defects with high activity.

H2O2 is a valuable, environmentally friendly oxidizing agent with a wide range of uses from the provision of clean H2O to the synthesis of valuable chems. The on-site electrolytic prodn. of H2O2 would bring the chem. to applications beyond its present reach. The successful commercialization of electrochem. H2O2 prodn. requires cathode catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and stability. In this Perspective, the authors highlight the authors' current understanding of the factors that control the cathode performance. The authors review the influence of catalyst material, electrolyte, and the structure of the interface at the mesoscopic scale. The authors provide original theor. data on the role of the geometry of the active site and its influence on activity and selectivity. The authors have also conducted original expts. on (i) the effect of pH on H2O2 prodn. on glassy C, pure metals, and metal-Hg alloys, and (ii) the influence of cell geometry and mass transport in liq. half-cells in comparison to membrane electrode assemblies.

A review. From an economic perspective, textile and paper bleaching are amongst the most important oxidn. processes. The removal of unwanted chromophores, be it stains on cloths or residual lignin in wood pulp, consumes more than 60% of the world prodn. of hydrogen peroxide. However, existing technologies have their limitations. At ambient temp., hydrogen peroxide gives little stain bleaching and is used inefficiently. Hence the high product dosages and washing temps. required limit its application to predominantly European markets, to the exclusion of the majority of the world's population. In paper manuf., the use of chlorine-based oxidants results in the formation of chlorinated waste products, which show poor biodegradability. On the other hand, hydrogen peroxide requires higher temps., longer reaction times and is more expensive. Transition-metal catalysts offer an alternative. This review discusses the main classes of known bleach catalysts and their possible modes of action.

A review. Electrochem. prodn. of H2O2 from O2 is a promising alternative to the energy-intensive anthraquinone process that is currently used as an industry std. Although most research on the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) has focused on the 4-electron pathway to water relevant to fuel cells, the 2-electron ORR to produce H2O2 is also of significant com. interest. The first half of this Perspective deals with the progress made in developing noble metal, carbon-based, and single-atom electrocatalysts and highlights the design strategies employed to obtain high selectivity toward H2O2. The second half addresses the challenges of large-scale prodn. and how results obtained using a rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) can be translated into com. viable flow cells. This Perspective focuses on the design of catalysts and cells that will enable industrial-scale electrochem. H2O2 prodn.

H2O2 is a valuable, environmentally friendly oxidizing agent with a wide range of uses from the provision of clean H2O to the synthesis of valuable chems. The on-site electrolytic prodn. of H2O2 would bring the chem. to applications beyond its present reach. The successful commercialization of electrochem. H2O2 prodn. requires cathode catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and stability. In this Perspective, the authors highlight the authors' current understanding of the factors that control the cathode performance. The authors review the influence of catalyst material, electrolyte, and the structure of the interface at the mesoscopic scale. The authors provide original theor. data on the role of the geometry of the active site and its influence on activity and selectivity. The authors have also conducted original expts. on (i) the effect of pH on H2O2 prodn. on glassy C, pure metals, and metal-Hg alloys, and (ii) the influence of cell geometry and mass transport in liq. half-cells in comparison to membrane electrode assemblies.

Hydrogen peroxide is a 'green' oxidant whose relatively high cost has prevented it from being applied to commodity chem. processing. In large part, those attributes of the current process (the anthraquinone route) that contribute to the cost of H2O2 also contribute to its non-sustainable features; byproduct streams, energy input, and multiple required unit operations. We have explored the generation of hydrogen peroxide directly from hydrogen and oxygen using liq. CO2 as the solvent and a CO2-sol. palladium catalyst. Producing H2O2 directly from H2 and O2 eliminates unit operations and reduces raw material costs significantly. Further, homogeneous reaction in liq. CO2 allows for contact between significant concns. of O2 and H2, high rate of reaction, and ready recovery of the product via stripping into water. Both Pd(II) and Pd(0) catalysts were explored for the reaction; our results suggest that future work should focus on optimization of a CO2-sol. or dispersible Pd(0) catalyst.

Acidic niobia-silica (NbS, 4-14 wt % Nb) materials used as supports of dispersed Pd particles (1.0-2.0 wt % Pd) have been prepd. from different Nb-precursors (niobium ethoxide, NBE, and ammonium niobium oxalate, ANBO) and techniques (copptn. and deposition), characterized, and tested in the direct synthesis of H2O2 in water and methanol solvents. In particular, on a typical NbS sample, the evolution of morphol. (by N2-adsorption-desorption), cryst.-phase (by XRD), electronic structure (by UV-vis-DRS), and surface acidity with time/temp. of treatment (350-800 °C for 4-100 h) has been investigated. Surface acidity was measured by titrns. with 2-phenylethylamine adsorption in various liqs.: cyclohexane, for the intrinsic acidity, and water, methanol, and water-methanol mixts. for the effective acidities. Direct H2O2 synthesis reaction was performed in semi-batch slurry reactor with continuous feeding of the gaseous mixt. (H2, O2, and N2), under pressure (5 × 103 kPa or 104 kPa) at 5 °C in methanol or in water. In both solvents, reaction rates only little decreased with time on stream, ca. 5% of rate decrease after 4 h of reaction from initial rate of ca. 0.5 gH2O2·(kgsolution·min)-1, according with the slight Pd sintering obsd. by TEM images. Catalysts prepd. by deposition of NBE on silica gave better performances than those prepd. from ANBO. In general, selectivity to H2O2 in water and in methanol was obsd. to be similar; the unexpected good selectivity in water was due to the higher effective acid strengths of the catalytic surfaces in water than in methanol, as exptl. proven.

Pd-based catalysts in which the Pd is alloyed with a transition metal (TM) are often considered for the direct synthesis of H2O2. In particular, PdAu and PdHg alloys are known for their good catalytic activities. However, finding suitable catalysts with designed compns. is not easy and the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms behind their enhanced activities is often lacking. In the current study, descriptor sets for direct H2O2 synthesis on Pd, PdAu, and PdHg surfaces were proposed based on d. functional theory. By considering the surface electronic effects caused by the alloy surface compn., descriptor sets consisting of the adsorption energy for reaction intermediates such as O2, O, and OOH and activation energy barriers were derived from elementary reaction steps. The geometric factors of the adsorbed species were also considered, but found to be less important. The adsorption energies of O2 and O were calcd. and compared to det. that surface-adsorbed O*2 is the intermediate species required to form the desired product. The selectivity was assessed by comparing the adsorption energies of O and OOH. Considering the main thermodn. and kinetic characteristics, the results showed that the PdHg alloy with a surface compn. having the at. ratio 2 : 1 gives the best selectivity. The results of the descriptor anal. indicated that alloying Pd with less active metals, such as Hg and Au, is a key strategy for designing catalysts with better catalytic activity and selectivity.

A review. H2O2 is important in large-scale industrial processes and smaller on-site activities. The present industrial route to H2O2 involves hydrogenation of an anthraquinone and O2 oxidn. of the resulting dihydroanthraquinone - a costly method and one that is impractical for routine on-site use. Electrosynthesis of H2O2 is cost-effective and applicable on both large and small scales. This Review describes methods to design and assess electrode materials for H2O2 electrosynthesis. H2O2 can be prepd. by oxidizing H2O at efficient anodic catalysts such as those based on BiVO4. Alternatively, H2O2 forms by partially reducing O2 at cathodes featuring either noble metal alloys or doped carbon. In addn. to the catalyst materials used, one must also consider the form and geometry of the electrodes and the type of reactor in order to strike a balance between properties such as mass transport and electroactive area, both of which substantially affect both the selectivity and rate of reaction. Research into catalyst materials and reactor designs is arguably quite mature, such that the future of H2O2 electrosynthesis will instead depend on the design of complete and efficient electrosynthesis systems, in which the complementary properties of the catalysts and the reactor lead to optimal selectivity and overall yield.

The direct synthesis of H2O2 (DSH) from H and O is an attractive prodn. route due to its green nature. However, it faces multiple tech. challenges, the biggest being the explosion risk of the flammable gas mixt. Herein we used microreactors to perform the reaction in an inherently safer way which allows the H concn. to fall within the explosion limit range. For the 1st time, we have studied the flame propagation phenomena inside a microreactor to det. the optimum channel dimension for DSH. A mechanism of fast synthesis and slow destruction has been proposed via study on the influence of channel length and liq. flow rate. Besides, a variety of reaction parameters including gas flow rate, O: H ratio, catalyst compn. and gas pressure have been studied carefully. The successful employment of a microreactor in this case indicated the potential of using microreactors to inhibit the explosion risks of hazardous processes.

A review of processes of prodn. of hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is widely used in almost all industrial areas, particularly in the chem. industry and environmental protection. The only degrdn. product of its use is water, and thus it has played a large role in environmentally friendly methods in the chem. industry. Hydrogen peroxide is produced on an industrial scale by the anthraquinone oxidn. process. However, this process can hardly be considered a green method. It involves the sequential hydrogenation and oxidn. of an alkylanthraquinone precursor dissolved in a mixt. of org. solvents followed by liq.-liq. extn. to recover H2O2. The anthraquinone oxidn. process is a multistep method that requires significant energy input and generates waste, which has a neg. effect on its sustainability and prodn. costs. The transport, storage, and handling of bulk H2O2 involve hazards and escalating expenses. Thus, novel, cleaner methods for the prodn. of H2O2 are being explored. The direct synthesis of H2O2 from O2 and H2 using a variety of catalysts, and the factors influencing the formation and decompn. of H2O2 are examd.

Water is a life-giving source, yet over a billion people lack access to clean drinking water. The present techniques for water treatment such as piped, treated water rely on time and resource intensive centralized solns. In this work, we propose a decentralized device concept that can utilize sunlight to split water into hydrogen and hydrogen peroxide. The hydrogen peroxide can oxidize orgs. while the hydrogen bubbles out. In enabling this device, we require an electrocatalyst that can oxidize water while suppressing the thermodynamically favored oxygen evolution and form hydrogen peroxide. Using d. functional theory calcns., we show that the free energy of adsorbed OH* can be used to det. selectivity trends between the 2e- water oxidn. to H2O2 and the 4e- oxidn. to O2. We show that materials which bind oxygen intermediates sufficiently weakly, such as SnO2, can activate hydrogen peroxide evolution. We present a rational design principle for the selectivity in electrochem. water oxidn. and identify new material candidates that could perform H2O2 evolution selectively.

The formation of H2O2 and org. peroxides in illuminated aq. suspensions of ZnO, TiO2, and desert sand in the presence of O and org. electron donors was studied. The photocatalytic rate of formation of H2O2 on ZnO depends on the O partial pressure, on the concn. of org. electron donors, and on the concn. of H2O2. During the initial phase of irradn., the rate prodn. of H2O2 is given by d[H2O2]/dt = (Φ0 - Φ1[H2O2])(d[hν]abs)/dt), where Φ0 is the quantum yield for H2O2 formation, Φ1 is the quantum yield for H2O2 degrdn., and d[hν]abs/dt is the photon flux. The steady-state concn. of H2O2 is independent of the absorbed photon flux as predicted by the above equation; [H2O2]ss = Ψ0/Ψ1. Steady-state concns. of H2O2 of >100μM were obtained in illuminated suspensions of ZnO. In the case of ZnO, the quantum yield for H2O2 formation, Ψ0, approached 15% at 330 nm, whereas the photodegrdn. reactions were relatively inefficient. The Ψ0 for TiO2 (1% at 330 nm) was an order of magnitude less than the value for ZnO. The Ψ0 for a sample of desert sand (Death Valley, California) was 10-4. Photooxidn. of acetate and other org. electron donors on colloidal ZnO produce substantial concns. of org. peroxides, ROOH. Illumination of ZnO suspensions contg. acetate produced >40% of the measured total peroxide (H2O2 and ROOH) as ROOH.

Reactive radicals such as hydroxyl radical (OH•), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and superoxide anion (O2-) are the main power driving titanium dioxide (TiO2) photocatalytic reactions, for example, photoinduced killing of biol. cells. The effect of copper ions on the formation of H2O2 over photocatalytic TiO2 was investigated. Under an oxygen-purged soln., formation of H2O2 was increased dramatically up to 20 times by the addn. of a small amt. of copper ions. By using the Fenton reaction, the H2O2 formed can be converted into OH•, a highly reactive radical. In contrast, under nitrogen-purged soln., no H2O2 was formed even in the presence of an electron acceptor, silver ion (Ag+). These results clearly show that H2O2 was generated from the redn. site of the photoexcited TiO2 and indicate an effective way to increase the photocatalytic efficiency.

The redn. of mol. oxygen is the counter reaction of most photocatalytic reactions proceeding oxidatively on titanium dioxide particles. We have quant. analyzed the reductive prodn. of hydrogen peroxide and superoxide ion from oxygen in an aq. soln. contg. 2-propanol as the scavenger of pos. holes. The rates for the prodn. of hydrogen peroxide and superoxide ion were detd. by colorimetry using iodide and nitroblue tetrazolium, resp. In addn., the oxidn. of 2-propanol to acetone was monitored. Based on a comparison of these prodn. rates, it was concluded that the main product from oxygen is hydrogen peroxide when TiO2 powder consisting mainly of anatase-form particles is used, whereas the main product is superoxide ion when TiO2 powder consisting mainly of rutile-form particles is used. The difference in the photocatalytic activity between these powders can be attributed to the difference between the redn. paths of oxygen on these powders. It was also found that the superoxide ion generated from mol. oxygen spontaneously reacts with 2-propanol to produce acetone and hydrogen peroxide.

There is a current intense interest in water electrolysis as a means of generating or storing energy as hydrogen. The water oxidn. step typically requires high overpotentials, creating a significant energy loss in the process. Reported is water oxidn. over a MnOx electrocatalyst at low overpotentials (≈150 mV) in Bu ammonium bisulfate electrolytes (aq. 0.4 M and hydrated ionic liq. 50/50). The catalyst-electrolyte combination produces currents of the order of 1 mA cm-2 at 150 mV overpotential. A similar expt. in an inorg. electrolyte produces only negligible currents on this catalyst. The product is shown by permanganate oxidn. to be predominantly H2O2 dissolved in the electrolyte. This was confirmed by the prepn. of model solns. directly from H2O2 which were shown to behave similarly to the electrochem. prepd. solns. Ab initio calcn. of possible solvated H2O2 structures in the electrolyte suggests that the hydrogen peroxide is stabilized by a hydrogen bonded complex involving the amine. The H2O2 soln. is shown to be stable for several hours, to days, depending on the concn., but can be rapidly decompd. into oxygen by a MnO2 catalyst. The process could thus be of interest both as part of a water splitting scheme as well as a route to H2O2 for chem. use.

Piezo1 channels sense whole body physical activity to reset cardiovascular homeostasis and enhance performance
Rode, Baptiste; Shi, Jian; Endesh, Naima; Drinkhill, Mark J.; Webster, Peter J.; Lotteau, Sabine J.; Bailey, Marc A.; Yuldasheva, Nadira Y.; Ludlow, Melanie J.; Cubbon, Richard M.; Li, Jing; Futers, T. Simon; Morley, Lara; Gaunt, Hannah J.; Marszalek, Katarzyna; Viswambharan, Hema; Cuthbertson, Kevin; Baxter, Paul D.; Foster, Richard; Sukumar, Piruthivi; Weightman, Andrew; Calaghan, Sarah C.; Wheatcroft, Stephen B.; Kearney, Mark T.; Beech, David J.

Nature Research

Mammalian biol. adapts to phys. activity but the mol. mechanisms sensing the activity remain enigmatic. Recent studies have revealed how Piezo1 protein senses mech. force to enable vascular development. Here, we address Piezo1 in adult endothelium, the major control site in phys. activity. Mice without endothelial Piezo1 lack obvious phenotype but close inspection reveals a specific effect on endothelium-dependent relaxation in mesenteric resistance artery. Strikingly, the Piezo1 is required for elevated blood pressure during whole body phys. activity but not blood pressure during inactivity. Piezo1 is responsible for flow-sensitive non-inactivating non-selective cationic channels which depolarize the membrane potential. As fluid flow increases, depolarization increases to activate voltage-gated Ca2+ channels in the adjacent vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasoconstriction. Phys. performance is compromised in mice which lack endothelial Piezo1 and there is wt. loss after sustained activity. The data suggest that Piezo1 channels sense phys. activity to advantageously reset vascular control.

Electrochem. synthesis of H2O2 via 2-electron H2O oxidn. reaction (2e-WOR) is an ideal process for delocalized prodn. for H2O cleaning and other applications. Previously reported H2O oxidn. catalysts have limited activity and selectivity, imposing a bottleneck for broad adoption of this technol. The authors identify ZnO as a new stable, nontoxic, active, and selective catalyst for 2e-WOR to generate H2O2. Using d. functional theory calcns., probably the (1010) facet of ZnO is an effective catalyst for 2e-WOR and confirm the prediction exptl. The authors synthesize ZnO nanoparticles with a high fraction of (1010) facets and find that this catalyst gives an overpotential of 40 mV at 0.1 mA/cm2 and peak faradaic efficiency of 81% toward H2O2 evolution.

Platinum group metal (PGM)-free catalysts for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) have attracted increasing interest as potential candidates to replace Pt, in the view of a future widespread commercialization of polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEFC) devices, esp. for automotive applications. Among different types of PGM-free catalysts, M-N-C materials appear to be the most promising ones in terms of activity. These catalysts can be produced using a wide variety of precursors contg. C, N, and one (or more) active transition metal (mostly Fe or Co). The catalysts synthesis methods can be very different, even though they usually involve at least one pyrolysis step. In this review, five different synthesis methods are proposed, and described in detail. Several catalysts, produced approx. in the last decade, were analyzed in terms of performance in rotating disc electrode (RDE), and in H2/O2 or H2/air PEFC. The catalysts are subdivided in five different categories corresponding to the five synthesis methods described, and the RDE and PEFC performance is put in relation with the synthesis method.

There is a growing interest in pursuing Fe-free and none-Pt-based electrocatalysts for oxygen redn. to obviate the harmful Fe-involved Fenton reaction. An efficient Mn-N-C electrocatalyst toward oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) was prepd. from direct pyrolysis of a Mn(II)-based MOF (named Mn-TTPBA-4) followed by acid leaching and 2nd heat-treatment, which was solvothermally synthesized from Mn(ClO4)2 and N-rich org. linker of TTPBA-4 [N1,N1,N4,N4-tetrakis[4-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)phenyl]benzene-1,4-diamine]. Single crystal x-ray diffraction anal. reveals that Mn-TTPBA-4 shows a 3-dimensional cationic porous architecture assembled by 1-dimensional ribbon chains extending in mutually vertical directions. The best-performing Mn-N-C catalyst exhibits a half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.81 V (vs. RHE) in alk. electrolyte comparable to the ref. Pt/C, and a good long-term stability with only 10 mV neg. shift in E1/2 after 10,000 cycles.

C-based materials are considered to be active for electrochem. O redn. reaction (ORR) to H2O2 prodn. Nevertheless, less attention is paid to the study of the influence of in-plane C lattice defect on the catalytic activity and selectivity toward ORR. Graphene precursors were prepd. from oxo-functionalized graphene (oxo-G) and graphene oxide (GO) with H2O2 hydrothermal treatment, resp. Statistical Raman spectroscopy (SRS) anal. demonstrated the increased in-plane C lattice defect d. in the order of oxo-G, oxo-G/H2O2, GO, GO/H2O2. Also, N-doped graphene materials were prepd. through ammonium hydroxide hydrothermal treatment of those graphene precursors. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) results indicate that the N-doped graphene derived from oxo-G with lowest in-plane C lattice defects exhibited the highest H2O2 selectivity of >82% in 0.1M KOH. Also, a high H2O2 prodn. rate of 224.8 mmol gcatalyst-1 h-1 could be achieved at 0.2 VRHE in H-cell with faradaic efficiency of >43.6%. The authors' work provides insights for the design and synthesis of C-based electrocatalysts for H2O2 prodn.

Electro-Fenton process is an emerging treatment technol. for water and wastewater treatment. Electro-Fenton utilizes hydroxyl radicals to oxidize hazardous contaminants and is esp. useful to treat recalcitrant compds. that are not easily degraded in conventional water and wastewater treatment plants. This paper reviews the mechanism of electro-Fenton process and its kinetic modeling. The effects of electrode materials, hydrogen peroxide concn., ferrous ion concn., pH, electrolyte, oxygen sparging rate, temp., initial concn. of pollutant, feeding mode, c.d., and distance between electrodes are also reviewed. The performance of electro-Fenton is compared with other treatment technologies. Finally, existing challenges and future perspectives are discussed.

H2O2 prodn. by electroredn. of O2 is an attractive alternative to the current anthraquinone process, which is highly desirable for chem. industries and environmental remediation. However, it remains a great challenge to develop cost-effective electrocatalysts for H2O2 synthesis. Here, hierarchically porous carbon (HPC) is proposed for the electrosynthesis of H2O2 from O2 redn. It exhibited high activity for O2 redn. and good H2O2 selectivity (95.0-70.2 %, most of them >90.0% at pH 1-4 and >80.0% at pH 7). High-yield H2O2 generation was achieved on HPC with H2O2 concns. of 222.6-62.0 mmol L-1 (2.5 h) and corresponding H2O2 prodn. rates of 395.7-110.2 mmol h-1 g-1 at pH 1-7 and -0.5 V. Also, HPC was energy-efficient for H2O2 prodn. with current efficiency of 81.8-70.8%. The exceptional performance of HPC for electrosynthesis of H2O2 could be attributed to its high content of sp3-C and defects, large surface area and fast mass transfer.

In this work, the synthesis and assessment are reported of a new non-precious-metal oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) catalyst from pyrolysis of an iron-coordinated complex which manifests superior activity in both alk. and acidic media. 11,11'-bis(dipyrido[3,2-a:2',3'-c]phenazinyl) (bidppz) was selected as a ligand for the formation of a nitrogen-rich iron-coordinated coordination polymer (Fe-bidppz) which forms a self-supporting catalyst contg. high densities of nitrogen and iron doping by pyrolysis. The catalyst pyrolyzed at 800° (Fe-N/C-800) shows the highest ORR activity with onset and half-wave potentials of 923 and 809 mV in 0.1 M KOH, resp., which are comparable to those of Pt/C (half-wave potential 818 mV vs. RHE) at the same catalyst loading. Besides, the Fe-N/C-800 catalyst has an excellent ORR activity with onset and half-wave potentials only 38 and 59 mV less than those of the Pt/C catalyst in 0.1 M HClO4. The optimal Fe-N/C-800 catalyst displays much greater durability and tolerance of methanol than Pt/C. It is proposed that the Fe-N/C-800 catalyst has a considerably high d. of surface active sites because Fe-N/C-800 possesses excellent ORR activity while its sp. surface area is not so high. Electrochem. measurements show that the Fe-N/C-800 catalyst in KOH and HClO4 follows the effective four-electron-transfer pathway.

Platinum-Based Oxygen Reduction Electrocatalysts
Wu, Jianbo; Yang, Hong
Accounts of Chemical Research
(

),

(
8

1848-1857
CODEN:

; ISSN:
0001-4842

(
American Chemical Society

A review. An efficient oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) offers the potential for clean energy generation in low-temp., proton-exchange membrane fuel cells running on hydrogen fuel and air. In the past several years, researchers have developed high-performance electrocatalysts for the ORR to address the obstacles of high cost of the Pt catalyst per kW of output power and of declining catalyst activity over time. Current efforts are focused on new catalyst structures that add a secondary metal to change the d-band center and the surface at. arrangement of the catalyst, altering the chemisorption of those oxygencontaining species that have the largest impact on the ORR kinetics and improving the catalyst activity and cost effectiveness. This Account reviews recent progress in the design of Pt-based ORR electrocatalysts, including improved understanding of the reaction mechanisms and the development of synthetic methods for producing catalysts with high activity and stability. Researchers have made several types of highly active catalysts, including an extended single crystal surface of Pt and its alloy, bimetallic nanoparticles, and self-supported, low-dimensional nanostructures. We focus on the design and synthetic strategies for ORR catalysts including controlling the shape (or facet) and size of Pt and its bimetallic alloys, and controlling the surface compn. and structure of core-shell, monolayer, and hollow porous structures. The strong dependence of ORR performance on facet and size suggests that synthesizing nanocrystals with large, highly reactive {111} facets could be as important, if not more important, to increasing their activity as simply making smaller nanoparticles. A newly developed carbon-monoxide (CO)-assisted redn. method produces Pt bimetallic nanoparticles with controlled facets. This CO-based approach works well to control shapes because of the selective CO binding on different, low-indexed metal surfaces. Post-treatment under different gas environments is also important in controlling the elemental distribution, esp. the surface compn. and the core-shell and bimetallic alloy nanostructures. Besides surface compn. and facet, surface strain plays an important role in detg. the ORR activity. The surface strain depends on the crystal size, the presence of an interface-lattice mismatch or twinned boundary, and between nanocrystals and extended single crystal surfaces, all of which may be factors in metal alloys. Since the common, effective reaction pathway for the ORR is a four-electron process and the surface binding of oxygen-contg. species is typically the limiting step, d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. is useful for predicting the ORR performance over bimetallic catalysts. Finally, we have noticed there are variations among the published values for activity and durability of ORR catalysts in recent papers. The differences are often due to the data quality and protocols used for carrying out the anal. using a rotating disk electrode (RDE). Thus, we briefly discuss some practices used in such half-cell measurements, such as sample prepn. and measurement, data reliability (in both kinetic c.d. and durability measurement) and iR correction that could lead to more consistency in measured values and in evaluating catalyst performances.

The direct electrochem. synthesis of H2O2 is a promising alternative to currently used batch synthesis methods. Its industrial viability is dependent on the effective catalysis of the redn. of O at the cathode. Herein, the authors study the factors controlling activity and selectivity for H2O2 prodn. on metal surfaces. Using this approach, the authors discover two new catalysts for the reaction, Ag-Hg and Pd-Hg, with unique electrocatalytic properties both of which exhibit performance that far exceeds the current state-of-the art.

A review on non-precious metal electrocatalysts for PEM fuel cells
Chen, Zhongwei; Higgins, Drew; Yu, Aiping; Zhang, Lei; Zhang, Jiujun
Energy & Environmental Science
(
2011
),
4
(
9
),
3167-3192
CODEN:

; ISSN:
1754-5706
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. With the approaching commercialization of PEM fuel cell technol., developing active, inexpensive non-precious metal ORR catalyst materials to replace currently used Pt-based catalysts is a necessary and essential requirement in order to reduce the overall system cost. This review paper highlights the progress made over the past 40 years with a detailed discussion of recent works in the area of non-precious metal electrocatalysts for oxygen redn. reaction, a necessary reaction at the PEM fuel cell cathode. Several important kinds of unsupported or carbon supported non-precious metal electrocatalysts for ORR are reviewed, including non-pyrolyzed and pyrolyzed transition metal nitrogen-contg. complexes, conductive polymer-based catalysts, transition metal chalcogenides, metal oxides/carbides/nitrides/oxynitrides/carbonitrides, and enzymic compds. Among these candidates, pyrolyzed transition metal nitrogen-contg. complexes supported on carbon materials (M-Nx/C) are considered the most promising ORR catalysts because they have demonstrated some ORR activity and stability close to that of com. available Pt/C catalysts. Although great progress has been achieved in this area of research and development, there are still some challenges in both their ORR activity and stability. Regarding the ORR activity, the actual volumetric activity of the most active non-precious metal catalyst is still well below the DOE 2015 target. Regarding the ORR stability, stability tests are generally run at low current densities or low power levels, and the lifetime is far shorter than targets set by DOE. Therefore, improving both the ORR activity and stability are the major short and long term focuses of non-precious metal catalyst research and development. Based on the results achieved in this area, several future research directions are also proposed and discussed in this paper.

Chung, Hoon T.; Cullen, David A.; Higgins, Drew; Sneed, Brian T.; Holby, Edward F.; More, Karren L.; Zelenay, Piotr

Platinum group metal-free (PGM-free) metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts have emerged as a promising alternative to their costly platinum (Pt)-based counterparts in polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs) but still face some major challenges, including (i) the identification of the most relevant catalytic site for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and (ii) demonstration of competitive PEFC performance under automotive-application conditions in the hydrogen (H2)-air fuel cell. Herein, we demonstrate H2-air performance gains achieved with an iron-nitrogen-carbon catalyst synthesized with two nitrogen precursors that developed hierarchical porosity. Current densities recorded in the kinetic region of cathode operation, at fuel cell voltages greater than ∼0.75 V, were the same as those obtained with a Pt cathode at a loading of 0.1 mg of Pt per cm squared. The proposed catalytic active site, carbon-embedded nitrogen-coordinated iron (FeN4), was directly visualized with aberration-cor. scanning transmission electron microscopy, and the contributions of these active sites assocd. with specific lattice-level carbon structures were explored computationally.

A review. The development of non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) that are practical for use at the cathode of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) would provide immense economic advantages, perpetuating the looming widespread commercialization of these devices. NPMC materials with excellent activity towards the oxygen redn., coupled with PEMFC performance approaching that of state-of-the-art platinum catalysts brings this technol. one step closer to practical application. Currently, the stability of these materials is still limited, and developing NPMC with excellent activity, performance and operational stability is the holy grail of PEMFC catalyst research. Fundamental knowledge available, along with recent progress made in this field of research will be the subject of this review paper.

Future generations require more efficient and localized processes for energy conversion and chem. synthesis. The continuous on-site prodn. of H2O2 would provide an attractive alternative to the present state-of-the-art, which is based on the complex anthraquinone process. The electrochem. redn. of O to H2O2 is a particularly promising means of achieving this aim. However, it would require active, selective and stable materials to catalyze the reaction. Although progress was made in this respect, further improvements through the development of new electrocatalysts are needed. Using d. functional theory calcns., the authors identify Pt-Hg as a promising candidate. Electrochem. measurements on Pt-Hg nanoparticles show more than an order of magnitude improvement in mass activity, i.e., A g-1 precious metal, for H2O2 prodn., over the best performing catalysts in the literature.

A review. Despite the dedicated search for novel catalysts for fuel cell applications, the intrinsic oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) activity of materials has not improved significantly over the past decade. Here, we review the role of theory in understanding the ORR mechanism and highlight the descriptor-based approaches that have been used to identify catalysts with increased activity. Specifically, by showing that the performance of the commonly studied materials (e.g., metals, alloys, carbons, etc.) is limited by unfavorable scaling relationships (for binding energies of reaction intermediates), we present a no. of alternative strategies that may lead to the design and discovery of more promising materials for ORR.

Activity-Selectivity Trends in the Electrochemical Production of Hydrogen Peroxide over Single-Site Metal-Nitrogen-Carbon Catalysts
Sun, Yanyan; Silvioli, Luca; Sahraie, Nastaran Ranjbar; Ju, Wen; Li, Jingkun; Zitolo, Andrea; Li, Shuang; Bagger, Alexander; Arnarson, Logi; Wang, Xingli; Moeller, Tim; Bernsmeier, Denis; Rossmeisl, Jan; Jaouen, Frederic; Strasser, Peter

(
2019
),
141
(
31
),
12372-12381
CODEN:
JACSAT
; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Nitrogen-doped carbon materials featuring atomically dispersed metal cations (M-N-C) are an emerging family of materials with potential applications for electrocatalysis. The electrocatalytic activity of M-N-C materials toward four-electron oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) to H2O is a mainstream line of research for replacing platinum-group-metal-based catalysts at the cathode of fuel cells. However, fundamental and practical aspects of their electrocatalytic activity toward two-electron ORR to H2O2, a future green "dream" process for chem. industry, remain poorly understood. Here we combined computational and exptl. efforts to uncover the trends in electrochem. H2O2 prodn. over a series of M-N-C materials (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) exclusively comprising atomically dispersed M-Nx sites from mol. first-principles to bench-scale electrolyzers operating at industrial c.d. We investigated the effect of the nature of a 3d metal within a series of M-N-C catalysts on the electrocatalytic activity/selectivity for ORR (H2O2 and H2O products) and H2O2 redn. reaction (H2O2RR). Co-N-C catalyst was uncovered with outstanding H2O2 productivity considering its high ORR activity, highest H2O2 selectivity, and lowest H2O2RR activity. The activity-selectivity trend over M-N-C materials was further analyzed by d. functional theory, providing mol.-scale understandings of exptl. volcano trends for four- and two-electron ORR. The predicted binding energy of HO* intermediate over Co-N-C catalyst is located near the top of the volcano accounting for favorable two-electron ORR. The industrial H2O2 productivity over Co-N-C catalyst was demonstrated in a microflow cell, exhibiting an unprecedented prodn. rate of more than 4 mol peroxide gcatalyst-1 h-1 at a c.d. of 50 mA cm-2.

Electrochemical processes on solid shaped nanoparticles with defined facets
Strasser, Peter; Gliech, Manuel; Kuehl, Stefanie; Moeller, Tim

A review. This 2007 Chem. Nobel prize update covers scientific advances of the past decade in our understanding of electrocatalytic processes on surfaces of nanoscale shape-controlled polyhedral solids. It is argued that the field of chem. reaction processes on solid surfaces has recently been paying increasing attention to the fundamental understanding of electrified solid-liq. interfaces and toward the operando study of the minute fraction of catalytically active, structurally dynamic non-equil. Taylor-type surface sites. Meanwhile, despite mounting evidence of acting as structural proxies in some cases, the concept of catalytic structure sensitivity of well-defined nanoscale solid surfaces continues to be a key organizing principle for the science of shape-controlled nanocrystals and, hence, constitutes a central recurring theme in this review. After addressing key aspects and recent progress in the wet-chem. synthesis of shaped nanocatalysts, three areas of electrocatalytic processes on solid shape-controlled nanocrystals of current scientific priority are discussed in more detail: the oxygen electroredn. on shape-controlled Pt-Ni polyhedra with its technol. relevance for low temp. fuel cells, the CO2 electroredn. to hydrocarbons on Cu polyhedra and the puzzling interplay between chem. and structural effects, and the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction from water on shaped transition metal oxides.

Beermann, Vera; Gocyla, Martin; Kuehl, Stefanie; Padgett, Elliot; Schmies, Henrike; Goerlin, Mikaela; Erini, Nina; Shviro, Meital; Heggen, Marc; Dunin-Borkowski, Rafal E.; Muller, David A.; Strasser, Peter

Shape-controlled octahedral Pt-Ni alloy nanoparticles exhibit remarkably high activities for the electroredn. of O2 (ORR), which makes them fuel cell cathode catalysts with exceptional potential. To unfold their full and optimized catalytic activity and stability, however, the nano-octahedra require post-synthesis thermal treatments, which alter the surface at. structure and compn. of the crystal facets. Here, the authors address and strive to elucidate the underlying surface chem. processes using a combination of ex situ anal. techniques with in situ TEM, in situ XRD, and in situ electrochem. Fourier transformed IR (FTIR) expts. The authors present a robust fundamental correlation between annealing temp. and catalytic activity, where a ∼ 25x higher ORR activity than com. Pt/C (2.7 A mgPt-1 at 0.9 VRHE) was reproducibly obsd. at annealing at 300°. The electrochem. stability, however, peaked without any and at the most severe heat treatments at 500°. Aberration-cor. scanning TEM (STEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDX) in combination with in situ electrochem. CO stripping/FTIR data revealed subtle, but important differences in the formation and chem. nature of Pt rich and Ni rich surface domains in the octahedral (111) facets. Estg. trends in surface chemisorption energies from in situ electrochem. CO / FTIR studies suggested that balanced annealing generates an optimal degree of Pt surface enrichment, while the others exhibited mostly Ni rich facets. The insights from the authors' study are quite generally valid and aid in developing suitable post synthesis thermal treatments for other alloy nanocatalysts as well.

Bacterial cellulose/polyaniline (BC/PANi) blends present a great potential for several applications. The current study evaluates the impact of using different BC matrixes (drained, freeze-dried and regenerated) and different synthesis conditions (in situ and ex situ) to improve the inherent properties of BC, which were monitored through FTIR-ATR, EDX, XRD, SEM, AFM, swelling, contact angle measurement and IGC. The employment of in situ polymn. onto drained BC presented the most conductive membrane (1.4×10-1S/cm). The crystallinity, swelling capacity, surface energy and acid/base behavior of the BC membranes is substantially modified upon PANi incorporation, being dependent on the BC matrix used, being the freeze-dried BC blends the ones with highest crystallinity (up to 54%), swelling capacity (up to 414%) and surface energy (up to 75.0 J/m2). Hence, this work evidenced that the final properties of the BC/PANi blends are greatly influenced by both the BC matrixes and synthesis methods employed.
