We adopted 1-step pyrolysis method to synthesize the Co nanoparticle-embedded, Ni and N co-doped carbon composites (Ni/Co/NC) by using ZIF-67 as precursor. We systematic analyzed the influence of Ni on its phys. and chem. properties. All samples were characterized by XRD, SEM, EDS, and TEM. The ORR activities were evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and rotating disk electrode (RDE) technol. Ni was successfully dispersed in Co/NC. The ORR onset potential of Co/NC is 0.847 V. When Co/NC was doped with 25%, 50%, and 75% Ni, its ORR onset potential is 0.854, 0.876, and 0.865 V, resp. 0.50Ni/Co/NC has dodecahedral morphol. and hollow structure. The Tafel slope value of Co/NC, 0.25Ni/Co/NC, 0.50Ni/Co/NC, and 0.75Ni/Co/NC is 0.97, 0.91, 0.82, and 0.89 mV/de, resp. 0.50Ni/Co/NC exhibits the most efficient properties for ORR.

C-based materials are considered to be active for electrochem. O redn. reaction (ORR) to H2O2 prodn. Nevertheless, less attention is paid to the study of the influence of in-plane C lattice defect on the catalytic activity and selectivity toward ORR. Graphene precursors were prepd. from oxo-functionalized graphene (oxo-G) and graphene oxide (GO) with H2O2 hydrothermal treatment, resp. Statistical Raman spectroscopy (SRS) anal. demonstrated the increased in-plane C lattice defect d. in the order of oxo-G, oxo-G/H2O2, GO, GO/H2O2. Also, N-doped graphene materials were prepd. through ammonium hydroxide hydrothermal treatment of those graphene precursors. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) results indicate that the N-doped graphene derived from oxo-G with lowest in-plane C lattice defects exhibited the highest H2O2 selectivity of >82% in 0.1M KOH. Also, a high H2O2 prodn. rate of 224.8 mmol gcatalyst-1 h-1 could be achieved at 0.2 VRHE in H-cell with faradaic efficiency of >43.6%. The authors' work provides insights for the design and synthesis of C-based electrocatalysts for H2O2 prodn.

Electrochemical processes on solid shaped nanoparticles with defined facets
Strasser, Peter; Gliech, Manuel; Kuehl, Stefanie; Moeller, Tim
Chemical Society Reviews
(
2018
),
47
(
3
),
715-735
CODEN:
CSRVBR
; ISSN:
0306-0012
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. This 2007 Chem. Nobel prize update covers scientific advances of the past decade in our understanding of electrocatalytic processes on surfaces of nanoscale shape-controlled polyhedral solids. It is argued that the field of chem. reaction processes on solid surfaces has recently been paying increasing attention to the fundamental understanding of electrified solid-liq. interfaces and toward the operando study of the minute fraction of catalytically active, structurally dynamic non-equil. Taylor-type surface sites. Meanwhile, despite mounting evidence of acting as structural proxies in some cases, the concept of catalytic structure sensitivity of well-defined nanoscale solid surfaces continues to be a key organizing principle for the science of shape-controlled nanocrystals and, hence, constitutes a central recurring theme in this review. After addressing key aspects and recent progress in the wet-chem. synthesis of shaped nanocatalysts, three areas of electrocatalytic processes on solid shape-controlled nanocrystals of current scientific priority are discussed in more detail: the oxygen electroredn. on shape-controlled Pt-Ni polyhedra with its technol. relevance for low temp. fuel cells, the CO2 electroredn. to hydrocarbons on Cu polyhedra and the puzzling interplay between chem. and structural effects, and the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction from water on shaped transition metal oxides.

A review. Electrochem. synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) provides a clean and safe technol. for large-scale H2O2 prodn. The core of this project is the development of highly active and highly selective catalysts. Recent studies demonstrate that carbonaceous materials are favorable catalysts because of their low-cost and tunable surface structures. This brief review first summarizes the strategies of carbonaceous material engineering for selective two-electron O2 redn. reaction and discusses potential mechanisms. In addn., several device designs using carbonaceous materials as catalysts for H2O2 prodn. are introduced. Finally, research directions are proposed for practical application and performance improvement.

Atomically dispersed manganese catalysts for oxygen reduction in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells
Li, Jiazhan; Chen, Mengjie; Cullen, David A.; Hwang, Sooyeon; Wang, Maoyu; Li, Boyang; Liu, Kexi; Karakalos, Stavros; Lucero, Marcos; Zhang, Hanguang; Lei, Chao; Xu, Hui; Sterbinsky, George E.; Feng, Zhenxing; Su, Dong; More, Karren L.; Wang, Guofeng; Wang, Zhenbo; Wu, Gang

CODEN:
NCAACP
; ISSN:
2520-1158
.

Platinum group metal (PGM)-free catalysts that are also iron free are highly desirable for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, as they avoid possible Fenton reactions. Here we report an efficient ORR catalyst that consists of atomically dispersed nitrogen-coordinated single Mn sites on partially graphitic carbon (Mn-N-C). Evidence for the embedding of the atomically dispersed MnN4 moieties within the carbon surface-exposed basal planes was established by X-ray absorption spectroscopy and their dispersion was confirmed by aberration-cor. electron microscopy with at. resoln. The Mn-N-C catalyst exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.80 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode, approaching that of Fe-N-C catalysts, along with significantly enhanced stability in acidic media. The encouraging performance of the Mn-N-C catalyst as a PGM-free cathode was demonstrated in fuel cell tests. First-principles calcns. further support the MnN4 sites as the origin of the ORR activity via a 4e- pathway in acidic media.

A review. Pyrolyzed metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) materials have become a mainstream research as inexpensive and sustainable catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in both acid and alk. media for low and intermediate temp. fuel cells. Tremendous advancements in the initial activity and power performance of M-N-C catalysts and cathodes have been achieved, as driven by their possible application in e.g. automotive fuel cell stacks. Based on a selected no. of recent studies, this review critically discusses the advancements, but also highlights the remaining scientific questions and tech. issues important in this field. The nature of the active site(s) as well as their intrinsic activity toward ORR have been clarified in particular through the prepn. of model catalysts comprising only MNxCy moieties. Recently developed methods hold promise to reliably enumerate the no. of electrochem. accessible active sites in such materials, which would allow deconvoluting the activity into site d. and turnover frequency.

Electrogeneration of hydrogen peroxide in acid medium using pyrolyzed cobalt-based catalysts: influence of the cobalt content on the electrode performance

Co tetramethoxyphenylporphyrin (CoTMPP) adsorbed on a high area C support (Vulcan XC72-R) and heat-treated at 900° under inert atm. was studied as electrocatalyst for the redn. of O2 to H2O2 in acid medium. Expts. performed on rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) and gas diffusion electrode (GDE) show that the catalyst performance depends on the Co loading, going through a max. at 0.2% Co. For higher Co loadings, a growing part of oxygen is reduced into H2O, decreasing therefore the selectivity of the catalyst. These results are interpreted in terms of a further redn. of H2O2 on Co-based catalytic sites before leaving the catalytic layer. For a GDE polarized at -150 mV vs. SCE and loaded with 0.9 μg cm-2 of 0.2% Co-based catalyst, a H2O2 prodn. rate of 300 μmol h-1 cm-2 was obtained which is 5 times higher than the H2O2 prodn. rate measured with Vulcan. Under these conditions, the selectivity of the Co-based catalyst for H2O2 prodn. is 92%. The good agreement obsd. between RRDE and GDE results confirms the relevance of using RRDE expt. for screening these nonprecious metal catalysts for further GDE applications.

The electrocatalysis of heat-treated Co-TPP/C for O2 redn. and H2O2 formation using a fuel cell reactor with an H2SO4 aq. electrolyte was studied (TPP: 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(phenyl)-21H,23H-porphyrin). C supports, including vapor grown C fiber (VGCF), activated C (a.c.), C black XC-72 (XC72), and C black Black-Pearl-2000/3500 (BP2000/3500), strongly affected the electrocatalysis of the Co-TPP/C. The Co-TPP/VGCF heat-treated at 1023 K, abbreviated as Co-TPP/VGCF(1073), showed a good electrocatalytic activity for H2O2 formation (1.0 mol dm-3 with 40% current efficiency (CE)); however, other C supports were unfavorable. Electrocatalytic activities were Co-TPP/VGCF(1073) >> Co-TPP/XC72(1073) > Co-TPP/AC(1073) > Co-TPP/BP2000(1073). Their electrocatalysis were studied by rotating ring-disk electrode voltammetry and kinetic studies of the decompn. of H2O2 and the electroredn. of H2O2 to H2O. The electrocatalytic activities for the successive redn. of H2O2 to H2O detd. the final H2O2 concns. and CEs. An active site of heat-treated Co-TPP/VGCF was characterized by XPS, and x-ray absorption near-edge fine structure spectroscopy. Partial pyrolysis of Co-TPP on the C surface was essential to generate the active site for the H2O2 formation. A model of the Co active site, CoN2-C, is proposed.

Gao, Jiajian; Yang, Hong bin; Huang, Xiang; Hung, Sung-Fu; Cai, Weizheng; Jia, Chunmiao; Miao, Shu; Chen, Hao Ming; Yang, Xiaofeng; Huang, Yanqiang; Zhang, Tao; Liu, Bin

The electrochem. oxygen redn. reaction in acidic media offers an attractive route for direct hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) generation and on-site applications. Unfortunately there is still a lack of cost-effective electrocatalysts with high catalytic performance. Here, we theor. designed and exptl. demonstrated that a cobalt single-atom catalyst (Co SAC) anchored in nitrogen-doped graphene, with optimized adsorption energy of the *OOH intermediate, exhibited a high H2O2 prodn. rate, which even slightly outperformed the state-of-the-art noble-metal-based electrocatalysts. The kinetic current of H2O2 prodn. over Co SAC could reach 1 mA/cm2disk at 0.6 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode in 0.1 M HClO4 with H2O2 faraday efficiency > 90%, and these performance measures could be sustained for 10 h without decay. Further kinetic anal. and operando X-ray absorption study combined with d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. demonstrated that the nitrogen-coordinated single Co atom was the active site and the reaction was rate-limited by the first electron transfer step.

The prohibitive cost of platinum for catalyzing the cathodic oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) has hampered the widespread use of polymer electrolyte fuel cells. We describe a family of non-precious metal catalysts that approach the performance of platinum-based systems at a cost sustainable for high-power fuel cell applications, possibly including automotive power. The approach uses polyaniline as a precursor to a carbon-nitrogen template for high-temp. synthesis of catalysts incorporating iron and cobalt. The most active materials in the group catalyze the ORR at potentials within ~60 mV of that delivered by state-of-the-art carbon-supported platinum, combining their high activity with remarkable performance stability for non-precious metal catalysts (700 h at a fuel cell voltage of 0.4 V) as well as excellent four-electron selectivity (hydrogen peroxide yield <1.0%).

Large-Scale and Highly Selective CO2 Electrocatalytic Reduction on Nickel Single-Atom Catalyst
Zheng, Tingting; Jiang, Kun; Ta, Na; Hu, Yongfeng; Zeng, Jie; Liu, Jingyue; Wang, Haotian

The scaling up of electrocatalytic CO2 redn. for practical applications is still hindered by a few challenges: low selectivity, small c.d. to maintain a reasonable selectivity, and the cost of the catalytic materials. Here we report a facile synthesis of earth-abundant Ni single-atom catalysts on com. carbon black, which were further employed in a gas-phase electrocatalytic reactor under ambient conditions. As a result, those single-at. sites exhibit an extraordinary performance in reducing CO2 to CO, yielding a c.d. above 100 mA cm-2, with nearly 100% selectivity for CO and around 1% toward the hydrogen evolution side reaction. By further scaling up the electrode into a 10 × 10-cm2 modular cell, the overall current in one unit cell can easily ramp up to more than 8 A while maintaining an exclusive CO evolution with a generation rate of 3.34 L hr-1 per unit cell.

The growth dynamics of bamboo-like multiwalled carbon nanotubes (BCNTs) via catalytic decompn. of C2H2 on Ni catalyst at 650 °C was obsd. in real time using an in situ ultrahigh vacuum transmission electron microscope. During BCNT growth, the shape of the catalyst particle changes constantly but remains metallic and cryst. Graphene sheets (bamboo knots) within the nanotube preferentially nucleate on the multistep Ni-graphite edges at the point where the graphene joins the catalyst particle, where it is stabilized by both the graphene walls and the Ni catalyst surface. The growth of a complete inner graphene layer prior to contraction of the Ni catalyst particle due to restoring cohesive forces will result in a complete BCNT knot whereas partial growth of the inner wall will lead to an incomplete BCNT knot.

Improved Electrochemical Phase Diagrams from Theory and Experiment: The Ni-Water System and Its Complex Compounds
Huang, L.-F.; Hutchison, M. J.; Santucci, R. J.; Scully, J. R.; Rondinelli, J. M.

Electrode potential-pH (Pourbaix) diagrams provide a phase map of the most stable compds. of a metal, its corrosion products, and assocd. ions in soln. The utility of these phase diagrams is that they enable the assessment of electrochem. stabilities, for example, of Ni metal and its derived oxides, hydroxides, and oxyhydroxides, against corrosion in aq. environments. Remarkably, the Ni Pourbaix diagrams reported over the last 50 years are largely inconsistent with various electrochem. observations, which may be attributed to inaccurate exptl. free energies of formation (ΔfG) for the complex Ni-based compds. used in producing the available diagrams. State-of-the-art d.-functional theory (DFT) can be used to obtain accurate ΔfG values, which lead to Ni Pourbaix diagrams that are more consistent with direct electrochem. expts.: Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy were used to characterize the electrochem. stabilities of NiO and Ni(OH)2 formed on Ni, demonstrating the reliability in correction-free 1st-principles based Pourbaix diagrams. The authors' results show the importance in applying modern d. functionals in combination with exptl. advances in aq. environment compd. identification for assessing electrochem. phase stability of materials, which will be useful for the design, synthesis, and selection of corrosion-resistant metals, photoabsorbers, and photocatalytic materials.

Electrochem. H2O2 (H2O2) prodn. by two-electron O redn. is a promising alternative process to the established industrial anthraquinone process. Current challenges relate to finding cost-effective electrocatalysts with high electrocatalytic activity, stability, and product selectivity. Here, the authors explore the electrocatalytic activity and selectivity toward H2O2 prodn. of a no. of distinct N-doped mesoporous C catalysts and report a previously unachieved H2O2 selectivity of ∼95-98% in acidic soln. To explain the authors' observations, the authors correlate their structural, compositional, and other physicochem. properties with their electrocatalytic performance and uncover a close correlation between the H2O2 product yield and the surface area and interfacial zeta potential. N doping was found to sharply boost H2O2 activity and selectivity. Chronoamperometric H2O2 electrolysis confirms the exceptionally high H2O2 prodn. rate and large H2O2 faradaic selectivity for the optimal N-doped CMK-3 sample in acidic, neutral, and alk. solns. In alk. soln., the catalytic H2O2 yield increases further, where the prodn. rate of the HO2- anion reaches a value ≤561.7 mmol gcatalyst-1 h-1 with H2O2 faradaic selectivity >70%. The authors' work provides a guide for the design, synthesis, and mechanistic study of advanced C-based electrocatalysts for H2O2 prodn.

By using first-principles calcns., we investigate the structural stability of nitrogen-doped (N-doped) graphene with graphitic-N, pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N, and the transition metal (TM) atoms embedded into N-doped graphene. The structures and energetics of TM atoms from Sc to Ni embedded into N-doped graphene are studied. The TM atoms at N4V 2 forming a 4N-centered structure shows the strongest binding and the binding energies are more than 7 eV. Finally, we investigate the catalytic performance of N-doped graphene with and without TM embedding for O2 dissocn., which is a fundamental reaction in fuel cells. Compared to the pyridinic-N, the graphitic-N is more favorable to dissoc. O2 mols. with a relatively low reaction barrier of 1.15 eV. However, the catalytic performance on pyridinic-N doped structure can be greatly improved by embedding TM atoms, and the energy barrier can be reduced to 0.61 eV with V atom embedded. Our results provide the stable structure of N-doped graphene and its potential applications in the oxygen redn. reactions. (c) 2015 American Institute of Physics.

Co-based catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in an acid medium were prepd. from Co acetate (Co(OAc)2) adsorbed on 9 different carbons (previously enriched in surface nitrogen or not). The catalysts were obtained by heat-treating these materials at 900° in a reducing environment rich in NH3. The emphasis was mainly placed on the electrochem. prodn. of H2O2 as measured by the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) technique. All Co-based catalysts are active for ORR. The activity and specificity of the catalysts for peroxide prodn. depend essentially on 3 factors: (i) the potential applied to the disk, (ii) the type of C support; and (iii) the concn. of the Co precursor. At identical Co loadings (2000 ppm), the percentage of peroxide produced at the disk (%H2O2) reaches a max. in the 0.3-0.1 V vs. SCE potential range and decreases for more neg. potentials. When the potential is set at a const. value (100 mV vs. SCE for instance), a strong effect of the C support on %H2O2 and on the ring current IR is noticed, with lower values of %H2O2 and IR corresponding to higher nitrogen content at the surface of the catalysts, while higher values of disk current ID are obtained under the same conditions. A figure of merit for the electroredn. of oxygen to H2O2 was obtained for each catalyst by multiplying ID (representing their activity for ORR) by %H2O2 (representing their specificity for H2O2 prodn.). According to this figure of merit, the best catalysts for peroxide prodn. are made with Ketjenblack, Black Pearls, Vulcan, and Norit C supports. For Co loadings >2000 ppm, increasing the loading by >1 order of magnitude (from 2000 to 50,000 ppm) has practically no effect on %H2O2 and IR, while ID decreases.

Objective evaluation of the activity of electrocatalysts for water oxidn. is of fundamental importance for the development of promising energy conversion technologies including integrated solar water-splitting devices, water electrolyzers, and Li-air batteries. However, current methods employed to evaluate oxygen-evolving catalysts are not standardized, making it difficult to compare the activity and stability of these materials. We report a protocol for evaluating the activity, stability, and Faradaic efficiency of electrodeposited oxygen-evolving electrocatalysts. In particular, we focus on methods for detg. electrochem. active surface area and measuring electrocatalytic activity and stability under conditions relevant to an integrated solar water-splitting device. Our primary figure of merit is the overpotential required to achieve a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 per geometric area, approx. the c.d. expected for a 10% efficient solar-to-fuels conversion device. Utilizing the aforementioned surface area measurements, one can det. electrocatalyst turnover frequencies. The reported protocol was used to examine the oxygen-evolution activity of the following systems in acidic and alk. solns.: CoOx, CoPi, CoFeOx, NiOx, NiCeOx, NiCoOx, NiCuOx, NiFeOx, and NiLaOx. The oxygen-evolving activity of an electrodeposited IrOx catalyst was also investigated for comparison. Two general observations are made from comparing the catalytic performance of the OER catalysts investigated: (1) in alk. soln., every non-noble metal system achieved 10 mA cm-2 current densities at similar operating overpotentials between 0.35 and 0.43 V, and (2) every system but IrOx was unstable under oxidative conditions in acidic solns.

Twelve well-characterized activated carbons with av. micropore widths between 0.7 and 2 nm, total surface areas of 378-1270 m2 g-1 and specific capacitances C up to 320 F g-1 were investigated, using H2SO4 2 M as electrolyte. Some of the carbons were also oxidized with (NH4)2S2O8, which leads to specific oxygen contents between 0.4-7.1 μmol m-2 of C surface area. It appears that Co, the limiting capacitance at a c.d. of 1 mA cm-2 of electrode surface, does not depend significantly on the O content. An empirical equation is proposed to describe the decrease of C with increasing c.d. d (1-70 mA cm-2 of electrode surface), as a function of the O content. As suggested by different authors, Co can be expressed as a sum of contributions from the external surface area Se and the surface of the micropores Smi. A closer investigation shows that Co/Smi increases with the pore size and reaches values as high as 0.250-0.270 F m-2 for supermicropores. It is suggested that the vol. W*0 of the electrolyte found between the surface layers in pores wider than 0.7-0.8 nm contributes to Co. However, this property is limited to microporosity, like the enthalpy of immersion of the carbons into benzene. The latter is also correlated to Co, which provides a useful means to identify potential supercapacitors.

A review. The electrochem. O redn. reaction (ORR) via the two-electron pathway provides a promising approach for the direct synthesis of H2O2 (H2O2) and its on-site uses. The effective electrocatalyst is one of the key factors detg. the future applications of this technol. In recent years, various catalysts, such as pristine C materials, modified C materials (oxidized or heteroatom doped such as N, F, or S doped), Au, or Hg alloyed Pd or Pt nanoparticles, as well as transition metal single atom catalysts (SACs) are reported to effectively catalyze the H2O2 prodn. via the two-electron ORR process. Among these candidates, SACs with 100% atom use and well-defined active centers attracted extra attention due to their high catalytic performance for H2O2 synthesis. In this review, the thermodn., O mol. activation, and theor. screening and prediction of SACs for electrochem. H2O2 synthesis are discussed. The catalytic performance, reaction kinetics and mechanism of SACs together with electrochem. devices for H2O2 synthesis via the two-electron ORR are summarized. It is hoped that this contribution can offer a comprehensive ref. for the progress of SACs in H2O2 electrochem. prodn. process.

We have investigated the impact of electrocatalyst loading on rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) expts. for the oxygen redn. reaction on Fe-N-C catalysts (ORR) in acid medium. In particular, the fraction of H2O2 produced as a function of catalyst loading was studied. A dramatic increase in H2O2 release was obsd. as the catalyst loading was decreased. For the same non-noble metal catalyst (NNMC), the fraction of produced H2O2 varied between less than 5% and greater than 95%, depending on the catalyst loading. These observations suggest that oxygen redn. occurs stepwise, via H2O2, and if the catalyst is sparsely loaded, the produced H2O2 cannot be efficiently reduced to H2O before it escapes. These studies have important implications for fundamental studies of ORR on NNMCs.

A highly active non-platinum group metal (non-PGM) catalyst derived from iron and 4-aminoantipyrine precursors was synthesized using a sacrificial support method (SSM) to obtain a highly porous, open framed structure. The ratio of iron to 4-aminoantipyrine had been previously optimized to catalyze the redn. of oxygen in both acid and alk. media. In this study, the mechanism of the redn. of oxygen in both media was investigated, and it was found to follow the 2 × 2 pathway. On its face, electrochem. anal. seems to suggest that the direct 4 electron transfer pathway is favored due to the low peroxide yield, but a closer examn. reveals that the 2 × 2 pathway is followed, where the fast step is the partial redn. to peroxide, and the ensuing redn. step to water is also fairly rapid.

The effect of catalyst loading levels on the O redn. reaction (ORR) selectivity for H2O formation on both N-contg. nanostructured C (CNx) and com. Pt/Vulcan C (VC) catalysts was examd. using the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) method. Catalyst loadings from 142 to 1420 μg/cm2 were studied. Catalyst loading played a significant role in detg. the selectivity for H2O formation, with lower loading levels showing a much higher selectivity for H2O2. The phenomenon was probed by examg. the exptl. collection efficiencies of the RRDE for each loading level and the catalyst thickness with SEM. The difference between exptl. and theor. collection efficiencies did not contribute significantly to the change in selectivity, although catalyst thickness did. Apparently a multistep mechanism where H2O2 is an intermediate can account for this behavior. More of this H2O2 intermediate can be detected when the reaction path length (catalyst thickness) is reduced. H2O2 electroredn. expts. showed the CNx materials to have the ability to catalyze further redn. of H2O2 to H2O, supporting the possibility of a two-step mechanism.

Metal, nitrogen-doped carbon materials have attracted interest as heterogenous catalysts that contain MNx active sites that are analogus to mol. catalysts. Of particular interest is Ni,N-doped carbon, a catalyst that is active for the electrochem. redn. of CO2 to CO. Crit. to the understanding of these materials is proof of single at. sites and characterization of the environment surrounding the metal atom; however, directly probing this coordination remains challenging. This challenge is addressed by combining scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), single atom electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS). Through STEM imaging, at. dispersion of Ni in the carbon framework is confirmed and image analyses are utilized to give semiquant. ests. of neighbor distance distributions and site densities of Ni atoms. Atomic resoln. EELS demonstrates that N and Ni are colocated at the single Ni atom sites suggesting Ni-N coordination. ToF-SIMS reveals a distribution of NiNxCy- fragments that reflect the Ni-N bonding environments within Ni,N-doped carbon. The fragmentation from Ni,N-doped carbon is similar to Ni phthalocyanine, suggesting the existence of heterogenized, mol.-like NiN4 active sites which motivates future studies that leverage insight from mol. catalysis design to develop next-generation heterogeneous catalysts.

Electrochem. redn. of CO2 (CO2) to value-added C products is a promising approach to reduce CO2 levels and mitigate the energy crisis. However, poor product selectivity is still a major obstacle to the development of CO2 redn. Here the authors demonstrate exclusive Ni-N4 sites through a topo-chem. transformation strategy, bringing unprecedentedly high activity and selectivity for CO2 redn. Topo-chem. transformation by C layer coating successfully ensures preservation of the Ni-N4 structure to a max. extent and avoids the agglomeration of Ni atoms to particles, providing abundant active sites for the catalytic reaction. The Ni-N4 structure exhibits excellent activity for electrochem. redn. of CO2 with particularly high selectivity, achieving high faradaic efficiency over 90% for CO in the potential range from -0.5 to -0.9 V and gives a max. faradaic efficiency of 99% at -0.81 V with a c.d. of 28.6 mA cm-2. The authors anticipate exclusive catalytic sites will shed new light on the design of high-efficiency electrocatalysts for CO2 redn.

Nickel and nitrogen co-doped carbon (Ni-N-C) has emerged as a promising catalyst for the CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR); however, the chem. nature of its active sites has remained elusive. Herein, the exploration is reported of the reactivity and active sites of Ni-N-C for the CO2RR. Single atom Ni coordinated with N confined in a carbon matrix was prepd. through thermal activation of chem. Ni-doped zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and directly visualized by aberration-cor. scanning transmission electron microscopy. Electrochem. results show the enhanced intrinsic reactivity and selectivity of Ni-N sites for the redn. of CO2 to CO, delivering a max. CO faradaic efficiency of 96% at a low overpotential of 570 mV. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. predict that the edge-located Ni-N2+2 sites with dangling bond-contg. carbon atoms are the active sites facilitating the dissocn. of the C-O bond of the *COOH intermediate, while bulk-hosted Ni-N4 is kinetically inactive. Furthermore, the high capability of edge-located Ni-N4 being able to thermodynamically suppress the competitive hydrogen evolution is also explained. The proposal of edge-hosed Ni-N2+2 sites provides new insight into designing high-efficiency Ni-N-C for CO2 redn.

Electrodeposited thin films and nanoparticles of Ni3S2 are highly active, poison- and corrosion-resistant catalysts for oxygen redn. to water at neutral pH. In pH 7 phosphate buffer, Ni3S2 displays catalytic onset at 0.8 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode, a Tafel slope of 109 mV/decade, and high faradaic efficiency for four-electron redn. of O2 to water. Under these conditions, the activity and stability of Ni3S2 exceeds that of polycryst. platinum and manganese, nickel, and cobalt oxides, illustrating the catalytic potential of pairing labile first-row transition metal active sites with a more covalent sulfide host lattice.

Oxygen reduction reaction mechanism and kinetics on M-NxCy and
[email protected]
active sites present in model M-N-C catalysts under alkaline and acidic conditions
Sgarbi, Ricardo; Kumar, Kavita; Jaouen, Frederic; Zitolo, Andrea; Ticianelli, Edson A.; Maillard, Frederic
Journal of Solid State Electrochemistry
(
2021
),
25
(
1
),
45-56
CODEN:
JSSEFS
; ISSN:
1432-8488
.
(
Springer
)
M-N-C electrocatalysts (where M is Fe or Co) have been investigated for mitigating the dependence on noble metals when catalyzing the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) for fuel cell technologies in acidic or alk. conditions. Rotating disk and rotating ring-disk electrode measurements for Fe-N-C and Co-N-C catalysts demonstrate promising performances and stability for the ORR, while the activity of main suspected active sites (M-NxCy and
[email protected]
) has been discussed on the basis of the known phys.-chem. properties of the catalysts in acid and alk. media. Thereupon, it is obsd. that atomically dispersed Fe-NxCy sites reach the highest ORR activity in acid media when amplified by an adequate energy binding between the metallic center and the oxygenated reaction intermediates. In contrast,
[email protected]
core-shell sites reach a max. ORR mass activity in alk. media through a synergistic effect involving catalyst particles with metallic iron in the core and nitrogen-doped carbon in the shell.
